chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 1

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 1:1
verses.text: The Instructor  Book 2.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:1
verses.text: Chapter - 1—On Eating.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:2
verses.text: Keeping, then, to our aim, and selecting the Scriptures which bear on the usefulness of training for life, we must now compendiously describe what the man who is called a Christian ought to be during the whole of his life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:3
verses.text: We must accordingly begin with ourselves, and how we ought to regulate ourselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:4
verses.text: We have therefore, preserving a due regard to the symmetry of this work, to say how each of us ought to conduct himself in respect to his body, or rather how to regulate the body itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:5
verses.text: For whenever any one, who has been brought away by the Word from external things, and from attention to the body itself to the mind, acquires a clear view of what happens according to nature in man, he will know that he is not to be earnestly occupied about external things, but about what is proper and peculiar to man—to purge the eye of the soul, and to sanctify also his flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:6
verses.text: For he that is clean rid of those things which constitute him still dust, what else has he more serviceable than himself for walking in the way which leads to the comprehension of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:7
verses.text: Some men, in truth, live that they may eat, as the irrational creatures, "whose life is their belly, and nothing else".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:8
verses.text: But the Instructor enjoins us to eat that we may live.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:9
verses.text: For neither is food our business, nor is pleasure our aim; but both are on account of our life here, which the Word is training up to immortality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:10
verses.text: Wherefore also there is discrimination to be employed in reference to food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:11
verses.text: And it is to be simple, truly plain, suiting precisely simple and artless children—as ministering to life, not to luxury.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:12
verses.text: And the life to which it conduces consists of two things—health and strength; to which plainness of fare is most suitable, being conducive both to digestion and lightness of body, from which come growth, and health, and right strength, not strength that is wrong or dangerous and wretched, as is that of athletes produced by compulsory feeding.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:13
verses.text: We must therefore reject different varieties, which engender various mischiefs, such as a depraved habit of body and disorders of the stomach, the taste being vitiated by an unhappy art—that of cookery, and the useless art of making pastry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:14
verses.text: For people dare to call by the name of food their dabbling in luxuries, which glides into mischievous pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:15
verses.text: Antiphanes, the Delian physician, said that this variety of viands was the one cause of disease; there being people who dislike the truth, and through various absurd notions abjure moderation of diet, and put themselves to a world of trouble to procure dainties from beyond seas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:16
verses.text: For my part, I am sorry for this disease, while they are not ashamed to sing the praises of their delicacies, giving themselves great trouble to get lampreys in the Straits of Sicily, the eels of the Maeander, and the kids found in Melos, and the mullets in Sciathus, and the mussels of Pelorus, the oysters of Abydos, not omitting the sprats found in Lipara, and the Mantinican turnip; and furthermore, the beetroot that grows among the Ascraeans: they seek out the cockles of Methymna, the turbots of Attica, and the thrushes of Daphnis, and the reddish-brown dried figs, on account of which the ill-starred Persian marched into Greece with five hundred thousand men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:17
verses.text: Besides these, they purchase birds from Phasis, the Egyptian snipes, and the Median peafowl.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:18
verses.text: Altering these by means of condiments, the gluttons gape for the sauces.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:19
verses.text: "Whatever earth and the depths of the sea, and the unmeasured space of the air produce," they cater for their gluttony.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:20
verses.text: In their greed and solicitude, the gluttons seem absolutely to sweep the world with a drag-net to gratify their luxurious tastes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:21
verses.text: These gluttons, surrounded with the sound of hissing frying-pans, and wearing their whole life away at the pestle and mortar, cling to matter like fire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:22
verses.text: More than that, they emasculate plain food, namely bread, by straining off the nourishing part of the grain, so that the necessary part of food becomes matter of reproach to luxury.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:23
verses.text: There is no limit to epicurism among men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:24
verses.text: For it has driven them to sweetmeats, and honey-cakes, and sugar-plums; inventing a multitude of desserts, hunting after all manner of dishes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:25
verses.text: A man like this seems to me to be all jaw, and nothing else.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:26
verses.text: "Desire not," says the Scripture, "rich men's dainties;" for they belong to a false and base life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:27
verses.text: They partake of luxurious dishes, which a little after go to the dunghill.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:28
verses.text: But we who seek the heavenly bread must rule the belly, which is beneath heaven, and much more the things which are agreeable to it, which "God shall destroy," says the apostle, justly execrating gluttonous desires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:29
verses.text: For "meats are for the belly," for on them depends this truly carnal and destructive life; whence some, speaking with unbridled tongue, dare to apply the name agape, to pitiful suppers, redolent of savour and sauces.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:30
verses.text: Dishonouring the good and saving work of the Word, the consecrated agape, with pots and pouring of sauce; and by drink and delicacies and smoke desecrating that name, they are deceived in their idea, having expected that the promise of God might be bought with suppers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:31
verses.text: Gatherings for the sake of mirth, and such entertainments as are called by ourselves, we name rightly suppers, dinners, and banquets, after the example of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:32
verses.text: But such entertainments the Lord has not called agapae.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:33
verses.text: He says accordingly somewhere, "When thou art called to a wedding, recline not on the highest couch; but when thou art called, fall into the lowest place;" and elsewhere, "When thou makest a dinner or a supper;" and again, "But when thou makest an entertainment, call the poor," for whose sake chiefly a supper ought to be made.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:34
verses.text: And further, "A certain man made a great supper, and called many".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:35
verses.text: But I perceive whence the specious appellation of suppers flowed: "from the gullets and furious love for suppers"—according to the comic poet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:36
verses.text: For, in truth, "to many, many things are on account of the supper".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:37
verses.text: For they have not yet learned that God has provided for His creature (man I mean) food and drink, for sustenance, not for pleasure; since the body derives no advantage from extravagance in viands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:38
verses.text: For, quite the contrary, those who use the most frugal fare are the strongest and the healthiest, and the noblest; as domestics are healthier and stronger than their masters, and husbandmen than the proprietors; and not only more robust, but wiser, as philosophers are wiser than rich men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:39
verses.text: For they have not buried the mind beneath food, nor deceived it with pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:40
verses.text: But love (agape) is in truth celestial food, the banquet of reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:41
verses.text: "It beareth all things, endureth all things, hopeth all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:42
verses.text: Love never faileth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:43
verses.text: "Blessed is he who shall eat bread in the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:44
verses.text: But the hardest of all cases is for charity, which faileth not, to be cast from heaven above to the ground into the midst of sauces.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:45
verses.text: And do you imagine that I am thinking of a supper that is to be done away with? "For if," it is said, "I bestow all my goods, and have not love, I am nothing".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:46
verses.text: On this love alone depend the law and the Word; and if "thou shalt love the Lord thy God and thy neighbour," this is the celestial festival in the heavens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:47
verses.text: But the earthly is called a supper, as has been shown from Scripture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:48
verses.text: For the supper is made for love, but the supper is not love (agape); only a proof of mutual and reciprocal kindly feeling.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:49
verses.text: "Let not, then, your good be evil spoken of; for the kingdom of God is not meat and drink," says the apostle, in order that the meal spoken of may not be conceived as ephemeral, "but righteousness, and peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:50
verses.text: He who eats of this meal, the best of all, shall possess the kingdom of God, fixing his regards here on the holy assembly of love, the heavenly Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:51
verses.text: Love, then, is something pure and worthy of God, and its work is communication.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:52
verses.text: "And the care of discipline is love," as Wisdom says; "and love is the keeping of the law".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:53
verses.text: And these joys have an inspiration of love from the public nutriment, which accustoms to everlasting dainties.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:54
verses.text: Love (agape), then, is not a supper.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:55
verses.text: But let the entertainment depend on love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:56
verses.text: For it is said, "Let the children whom Thou hast loved, O Lord, learn that it is not the products of fruits that nourish man; but it is Thy word which preserves those who believe on Thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:57
verses.text: "For the righteous shall not live by bread".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:58
verses.text: But let our diet be light and digestible, and suitable for keeping awake, unmixed with diverse varieties.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:59
verses.text: Nor is this a point which is beyond the sphere of discipline.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:60
verses.text: For love is a good nurse for communication; having as its rich provision sufficiency, which, presiding over diet measured in due quantity, and treating the body in a healthful way, distributes something from its resources to those near us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:61
verses.text: But the diet which exceeds sufficiency injures a man, deteriorates his spirit, and renders his body prone to disease.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:62
verses.text: Besides, those dainty tastes, which trouble themselves about rich dishes, drive to practices of ill-repute, daintiness, gluttony, greed, voracity, insatiability.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:63
verses.text: Appropriate designations of such people as so indulge are flies, weasels, flatterers, gladiators, and the monstrous tribes of parasites—the one class surrendering reason, the other friendship, and the other life, for the gratification of the belly; crawling on their bellies, beasts in human shape after the image of their father, the voracious beast.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:64
verses.text: People first called the abandoned ἀσώτους, and so appear to me to indicate their end, understanding them as those who are (ἀσώστους) unsaved, excluding the σ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:65
verses.text: For those that are absorbed in pots, and exquisitely prepared niceties of condiments, are they not plainly abject, earth-born, leading an ephemeral kind of life, as if they were not to live hereafter? Those the Holy Spirit, by Isaiah, denounces as wretched, depriving them tacitly of the name of love (agape), since their feasting was not in accordance with the word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:66
verses.text: "But they made mirth, killing calves, and sacrificing sheep, saying, Let us eat and drink, for to-morrow we die".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:67
verses.text: And that He reckons such luxury to be sin, is shown by what He adds, "And your sin shall not be forgiven you till you die,"—not conveying the idea that death, which deprives of sensation, is the forgiveness of sin, but meaning that death of salvation which is the recompense of sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:68
verses.text: "Take no pleasure in abominable delicacies, says Wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:69
verses.text: At this point, too, we have to advert to what are called things sacrificed to idols, in order to show how we are enjoined to abstain from them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:70
verses.text: Polluted and abominable those things seem to me, to the blood of which, fly  "Souls from Erebus of inanimate corpses".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:71
verses.text: "For I would not that ye should have fellowship with demons," says the apostle; since the food of those who are saved and those who perish is separate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:72
verses.text: We must therefore abstain from these viands not for fear (because there is no power in them); but on account of our conscience, which is holy, and out of detestation of the demons to which they are dedicated, are we to loathe them; and further, on account of the instability of those who regard many things in a way that makes them prone to fall, "whose conscience, being weak, is defiled: for meat commendeth us not to God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:73
verses.text: "For it is not that which entereth in that defileth a man, but that which goeth out of his mouth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:74
verses.text: The natural use of food is then indifferent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:75
verses.text: "For neither if we eat are we the better," it is said, "nor if we eat not are we the worse".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:76
verses.text: But it is inconsistent with reason, for those that have been made worthy to share divine and spiritual food, to partake of the tables of demons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:77
verses.text: "Have we not power to eat and to drink," says the apostle, "and to lead about wives"? But by keeping pleasures under command we prevent lusts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:78
verses.text: See, then, that this power of yours never "become a stumbling-block to the weak".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:79
verses.text: For it were not seemly that we, after the fashion of the rich man's son in the Gospel, should, as prodigals, abuse the Father's gifts; but we should use them, without undue attachment to them, as having command over ourselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:80
verses.text: For we are enjoined to reign and rule over meats, not to be slaves to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:81
verses.text: It is an admirable thing, therefore, to raise our eyes aloft to what is true, to depend on that divine food above, and to satiate ourselves with the exhaustless contemplation of that which truly exists, and so taste of the only sure and pure delight.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:82
verses.text: For such is the agape, which, the food that comes from Christ shows that we ought to partake of.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:83
verses.text: But totally irrational, futile, and not human is it for those that are of the earth, fattening themselves like cattle, to feed themselves up for death; looking downwards on the earth, and bending ever over tables; leading a life of gluttony; burying all the good of existence here in a life that by and by will end; courting voracity alone, in respect to which cooks are held in higher esteem than husbandmen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:84
verses.text: For we do not abolish social intercourse, but look with suspicion on the snares of custom, and regard them as a calamity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:85
verses.text: Wherefore daintiness is to be shunned, and we are to partake of few and necessary things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:86
verses.text: "And if one of the unbelievers call us to a feast, and we determine to go" (for it is a good thing not to mix with the dissolute), the apostle bids us "eat what is set before us, asking no questions for conscience sake".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:87
verses.text: Similarly he has enjoined to purchase "what is sold in the shambles," without curious questioning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:88
verses.text: We are not, then, to abstain wholly from various kinds of food, but only are not to be taken up about them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:89
verses.text: We are to partake of what is set before us, as becomes a Christian, out of respect to him who has invited us, by a harmless and moderate participation in the social meeting; regarding the sumptuousness of what is put on the table as a matter of indifference, despising the dainties, as after a little destined to perish.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:90
verses.text: "Let him who eateth, not despise him who eateth not; and let him who eateth not, not judge him who eateth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:91
verses.text: And a little way on he explains the reason of the command, when he says, "He that eateth, eateth to the Lord, and giveth God thanks; and he that eateth not, to the Lord he eateth not, and giveth God thanks".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:92
verses.text: So that the right food is thanksgiving.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:93
verses.text: And he who gives thanks does not occupy his time in pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:94
verses.text: And if we would persuade any of our fellow-guests to virtue, we are all the more on this account to abstain from those dainty dishes; and so exhibit ourselves as a bright pattern of virtue, such as we ourselves have in Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:95
verses.text: "For if any of such meats make a brother to stumble, I shall not eat it as long as the world lasts," says he, "that I may not make my brother stumble".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:96
verses.text: I gain the man by a little self-restraint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:97
verses.text: "Have we not power to eat and to drink?" And "we know"—he says the truth—"that an idol is nothing in the world; but we have only one true God, of whom are all things, and one Lord Jesus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:98
verses.text: But," he says, "through thy knowledge thy weak brother perishes, for whom Christ died; and they that wound the conscience of the weak brethren sin against Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:99
verses.text: Thus the apostle, in his solicitude for us, discriminates in the case of entertainments, saying, that "if any one called a brother be found a fornicator, or an adulterer, or an idolater, with such an one not to eat;" neither in discourse or food are we to join, looking with suspicion on the pollution thence proceeding, as on the tables of the demons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:100
verses.text: "It is good, then, neither to eat flesh nor to drink wine," as both he and the Pythagoreans acknowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:101
verses.text: For this is rather characteristic of a beast; and the fumes arising from them being dense, darken the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:102
verses.text: If one partakes of them, he does not sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:103
verses.text: Only let him partake temperately, not dependent on them, nor gaping after fine fare.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:104
verses.text: For a voice will whisper to him, saying, "Destroy not the work of God for the sake of food".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:105
verses.text: For it is the mark of a silly mind to be amazed and stupefied at what is presented at vulgar banquets, after the rich fare which is in the Word; and much sillier to make one's eyes the slaves of the delicacies, so that one's greed is, so to speak, carried round by the servants.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:106
verses.text: And how foolish for people to raise themselves on the couches, all but pitching their faces into the dishes, stretching out from the couch as from a nest, according to the common saying, "that they may catch the wandering steam by breathing it in!" And how senseless, to besmear their hands with the condiments, and to be constantly reaching to the sauce, cramming themselves immoderately and shamelessly, not like people tasting, but ravenously seizing! For you may see such people, liker swine or dogs for gluttony than men, in such a hurry to feed themselves full, that both jaws are stuffed out at once, the veins about the face raised, and besides, the perspiration running all over, as they are tightened with their insatiable greed, and panting with their excess; the food pushed with unsocial eagerness into their stomach, as if they were stowing away their victuals for provision for a journey, not for digestion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:107
verses.text: Excess, which in all things is an evil, is very highly reprehensible in the matter of food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:108
verses.text: Gluttony, called ὀψοφαγία, is nothing but excess in the use of relishes (ὄψον); and λαιμαργία is insanity with respect to the gullet; and γαστριμαργία is excess with respect to food—insanity in reference to the belly, as the name implies; for μάργος is a madman.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:109
verses.text: The apostle, checking those that transgress in their conduct at entertainments, says: "For every one taketh beforehand in eating his own supper; and one is hungry, and another drunken.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:110
verses.text: Have ye not houses to eat and to drink in? Or despise ye the church of God, and shame those who have not?" And among those who have, they, who eat shamelessly and are insatiable, shame themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:111
verses.text: And both act badly; the one by paining those who have not, the other by exposing their own greed in the presence of those who have.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:112
verses.text: Necessarily, therefore, against those who have cast off shame and unsparingly abuse meals, the insatiable to whom nothing is sufficient, the apostle, in continuation, again breaks forth in a voice of displeasure: "So that, my brethren, when ye come together to eat, wait for one another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:113
verses.text: And if any one is hungry, let him eat at home, that ye come not together to condemnation".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:114
verses.text: From all slavish habits and excess we must abstain, and touch what is set before us in a decorous way; keeping the hand and couch and chin free of stains; preserving the grace of the countenance undisturbed, and committing no indecorum in the act of swallowing; but stretching out the hand at intervals in an orderly manner.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:115
verses.text: We must guard against speaking anything while eating: for the voice becomes disagreeable and inarticulate when it is confined by full jaws; and the tongue, pressed by the food and impeded in its natural energy, gives forth a compressed utterance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:116
verses.text: Nor is it suitable to eat and to drink simultaneously.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:117
verses.text: For it is the very extreme of intemperance to confound the times whose uses are discordant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:118
verses.text: And "whether ye eat or drink, do all to the glory of God," aiming after true frugality, which the Lord also seems to me to have hinted at when He blessed  the loaves and the cooked fishes with which He feasted the disciples, introducing a beautiful example of simple food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:119
verses.text: That fish then which, at the command of the Lord, Peter caught, points to digestible and God-given and moderate food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:120
verses.text: And by those who rise from the water to the bait of righteousness, He admonishes us to take away luxury and avarice, as the coin from the fish; in order that He might displace vainglory; and by giving the stater to the tax-gatherers, and "rendering to Caesar the things which are Caesar's," might preserve "to God the things which are God's".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:121
verses.text: The stater is capable of other explanations not unknown to us, but the present is not a suitable occasion for their treatment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:122
verses.text: Let the mention we make for our present purpose suffice, as it is not unsuitable to the flowers of the Word; and we have often done this, drawing to the urgent point of the question the most beneficial fountain, in order to water those who have been planted by the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:123
verses.text: "For if it is lawful for me to partake of all things, yet all things are not expedient".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:124
verses.text: For those that do all that is lawful, quickly fall into doing what is unlawful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:125
verses.text: And just as righteousness is not attained by avarice, nor temperance by excess; so neither is the regimen of a Christian formed by indulgence; for the table of truth is far from lascivious dainties.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:126
verses.text: For though it was chiefly for men's sake that all things were made, yet it is not good to use all things, nor at all times.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:127
verses.text: For the occasion, and the time, and the mode, and the intention, materially turn the balance with reference to what is useful, in the view of one who is rightly instructed; and this is suitable, and has influence in putting a stop to a life of gluttony, which wealth is prone to choose, not that wealth which sees clearly, but that abundance which makes a man blind with reference to gluttony.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:128
verses.text: No one is poor as regards necessaries, and a man is never overlooked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:129
verses.text: For there is one God who feeds the fowls and the fishes, and, in a word, the irrational creatures; and not one thing whatever is wanting to them, though "they take no thought for their food".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:130
verses.text: And we are better than they, being their lords, and more closely allied to God, as being wiser; and we were made, not that we might eat and drink, but that we might devote ourselves to the knowledge of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:131
verses.text: "For the just man who eats is satisfied in his soul, but the belly of the wicked shall want," filled with the appetites of insatiable gluttony.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:132
verses.text: Now lavish expense is adapted not for enjoyment alone, but also for social communication.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:133
verses.text: Wherefore we must guard against those articles of food which persuade us to eat when we are not hungry, bewitching the appetite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:134
verses.text: For is there not within a temperate simplicity a wholesome variety of eatables? Bulbs, olives, certain herbs, milk, cheese, fruits, all kinds of cooked food without sauces; and if flesh is wanted, let roast rather than boiled be set down.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:135
verses.text: Have you anything to eat here? said the Lord to the disciples after the resurrection; and they, as taught by Him to practice frugality, "gave Him a piece of broiled fish;" and having eaten before them, says Luke, He spoke to them what He spoke.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:136
verses.text: And in addition to these, it is not to be overlooked that those who feed according to the Word are not debarred from dainties in the shape of honey-combs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:137
verses.text: For of articles of food, those are the most suitable which are fit for immediate use without fire, since they are readiest; and second to these are those which are simplest, as we said before.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:138
verses.text: But those who bend around inflammatory tables, nourishing their own diseases, are ruled by a most lickerish demon, whom I shall not blush to call the Belly-demon, and the worst and most abandoned of demons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:139
verses.text: He is therefore exactly like the one who is called the Ventriloquist-demon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:140
verses.text: It is far better to be happy than to have a demon dwelling with us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:141
verses.text: And happiness is found in the practice of virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:142
verses.text: Accordingly, the apostle Matthew partook of seeds, and nuts, and vegetables, without flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:143
verses.text: And John, who carried temperance to the extreme, "ate locusts and wild honey".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:144
verses.text: Peter abstained from swine; "but a trance fell on him," as is written in the Acts of the Apostles, "and he saw heaven opened, and a vessel let down on the earth by the four corners, and all the four-looted beasts and creeping things of the earth and the fowls of heaven in it; and there came a voice to him, Rise, and slay, and eat.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:145
verses.text: And Peter said, Not so, Lord, for I have never eaten what is common or unclean.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:146
verses.text: And the voice came again to him the second time, What God hath cleansed, call not thou common".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:147
verses.text: The use of them is accordingly indifferent to us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:148
verses.text: "For not what entereth into the mouth defileth the man," but the vain opinion respecting uncleanness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:149
verses.text: For God, when He created man, said, "All things shall be to you for meat".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:150
verses.text: "And herbs, with love, are better than a calf with fraud".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:151
verses.text: This well reminds us of what was said above, that herbs are not love, but that our meals are to be taken with love; and in these the medium state is good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:152
verses.text: In all things, indeed, this is the case, and not least in the preparation made for feasting, since the extremes are dangerous, and middle courses good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:153
verses.text: And to be in no want of necessaries is the medium.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:154
verses.text: For the desires which are in accordance with nature are bounded by sufficiency.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:155
verses.text: The Jews had frugality enjoined on them by the law in the most systematic manner.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:156
verses.text: For the Instructor, by Moses, deprived them of the use of innumerable things, adding reasons—the spiritual ones hidden; the carnal ones apparent, to which indeed they have trusted; in the case of some animals, because they did not part the hoof, and others because they did not ruminate their food, and others because alone of aquatic animals they were devoid of scales; so that altogether but a few were left appropriate for their food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:157
verses.text: And of those that he permitted them to touch, he prohibited such as had died, or were offered to idols, or had been strangled; for to touch these was unlawful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:158
verses.text: For since it is impossible for those who use dainties to abstain from partaking of them, he appointed the opposite mode of life, till he should break down the propensity to indulgence arising from habit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:159
verses.text: Pleasure has often produced in men harm and pain; and full feeding begets in the soul uneasiness, and forgetfulness, and foolishness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:160
verses.text: And they say that the bodies of children, when shooting up to their height, are made to grow right by deficiency in nourishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:161
verses.text: For then the spirit, which pervades the body in order to its growth, is not checked by abundance of food obstructing the freedom of its course.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:162
verses.text: Whence that truth-seeking philosopher Plato, fanning the spark of the Hebrew philosophy when condemning a life of luxury, says: "On my coming hither, the life which is here called happy, full of Italian and Syracusan tables, pleased me not by any means, consisting as it did in being filled twice a day, and never sleeping by night alone, and whatever other accessories attend the mode of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:163
verses.text: For not one man under heaven, if brought up from his youth in such practices, will ever turn out a wise man, with however admirable a natural genius he may be endowed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:164
verses.text: For Plato was not unacquainted with David, who "placed the sacred ark in his city in the midst of the tabernacle;" and bidding all his subjects rejoice "before the Lord, divided to the whole host of Israel, man and woman, to each a loaf of bread, and baked bread, and a cake from the frying-pan".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:165
verses.text: This was the sufficient sustenance of the Israelites.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:166
verses.text: But that of the Gentiles was over-abundant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:167
verses.text: No one who uses it will ever study to become temperate, burying as he does his mind in his belly, very like the fish called ass, which, Aristotle says, alone of all creatures has its heart in its stomach.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:168
verses.text: This fish Epicharmus the comic poet calls "monster-paunch".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:169
verses.text: Such are the men who believe in their belly, "whose God is their belly, whose glory is in their shame, who mind earthly things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 2:170
verses.text: To them the apostle predicted no good when he said, "whose end is destruction".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 2—On Drinking.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:2
verses.text: "Use a little wine," says the apostle to Timothy, who drank water, "for thy stomach's sake;" most properly applying its aid as a strengthening tonic suitable to a sickly body enfeebled with watery humours; and specifying "a little," lest the remedy should, on account of its quantity, unobserved, create the necessity of other treatment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:3
verses.text: The natural, temperate, and necessary beverage, therefore, for the thirsty is water.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:4
verses.text: This was the simple drink of sobriety, which, flowing from the smitten rock, was supplied by the Lord to the ancient Hebrews.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:5
verses.text: It was most requisite that in their wanderings they should be temperate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:6
verses.text: Afterwards the sacred vine produced the prophetic cluster.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:7
verses.text: This was a sign to them, when trained from wandering to their rest; representing the great cluster the Word, bruised for us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:8
verses.text: For the blood of the grape—that is, the Word—desired to be mixed with water, as His blood is mingled with salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:9
verses.text: And the blood of the Lord is twofold.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:10
verses.text: For there is the blood of His flesh, by which we are redeemed from corruption; and the spiritual, that by which we are anointed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:11
verses.text: And to drink the blood of Jesus, is to become partaker of the Lord's immortality; the Spirit being the energetic principle of the Word, as blood is of flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:12
verses.text: Accordingly, as wine is blended with water, so is the Spirit with man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:13
verses.text: And the one, the mixture of wine and water, nourishes to faith; while the other, the Spirit, conducts to immortality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:14
verses.text: And the mixture of both—of the water and of the Word—is called Eucharist, renowned and glorious grace; and they who by faith partake of it are sanctified both in body and soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:15
verses.text: For the divine mixture, man, the Father's will has mystically compounded by the Spirit and the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:16
verses.text: For, in truth, the spirit is joined to the soul, which is inspired by it; and the flesh, by reason of which the Word became flesh, to the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:17
verses.text: I therefore admire those who have adopted an austere life, and who are fond of water, the medicine of temperance, and flee as far as possible from wine, shunning it as they would the danger of fire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:18
verses.text: It is proper, therefore, that boys and girls should keep as much as possible away from this medicine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:19
verses.text: For it is not right to pour into the burning season of life the hottest of all liquids—wine—adding, as it were, fire to fire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:20
verses.text: For hence wild impulses and burning lusts and fiery habits are kindled; and young men inflamed from within become prone to the indulgence of vicious propensities; so that signs of injury appear in their body, the members of lust coming to maturity sooner than they ought.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:21
verses.text: The breasts and organs of generation, inflamed with wine, expand and swell in a shameful way, already exhibiting beforehand the image of fornication; and the body compels the wound of the soul to inflame, and shameless pulsations follow abundance, inciting the man of correct behaviour to transgression; and hence the voluptuousness of youth overpasses the bounds of modesty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:22
verses.text: And we must, as far as possible, try to quench the impulses of youth by removing the Bacchic fuel of the threatened danger; and by pouring the antidote to the inflammation, so keep down the burning soul, and keep in the swelling members, and allay the agitation of lust when it is already in commotion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:23
verses.text: And in the case of grown-up people, let those with whom it agrees sometimes partake of dinner, tasting bread only, and let them abstain wholly from drink; in order that their superfluous moisture may be absorbed and drunk up by the eating of dry food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:24
verses.text: For constant spitting and wiping off perspiration, and hastening to evacuations, is the sign of excess, from the immoderate use of liquids supplied in excessive quantity to the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:25
verses.text: And if thirst come on, let the appetite be satisfied with a little water.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:26
verses.text: For it is not proper that water should be supplied in too great profusion; in order that the food may not be drowned, but ground down in order to digestion; and this takes place when the victuals are collected into a mass, and only a small portion is evacuated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:27
verses.text: And, besides, it suits divine studies not to be heavy with wine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:28
verses.text: "For unmixed wine is far from compelling a man to be wise, much less temperate," according to the comic poet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:29
verses.text: But towards evening, about supper-time, wine may be used, when we are no longer engaged in more serious readings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:30
verses.text: Then also the air becomes colder than it is during the day; so that the failing natural warmth requires to be nourished by the introduction of heat.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:31
verses.text: But even then it must only be a little wine that is to be used; for we must not go on to intemperate potations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:32
verses.text: Those who are already advanced in life may partake more cheerfully of the draught, to warm by the harmless medicine of the vine the chill of age, which the decay of time has produced.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:33
verses.text: For old men's passions are not, for the most part, stirred to such agitation as to drive them to the shipwreck of drunkenness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:34
verses.text: For being moored by reason and time, as by anchors, they stand with greater ease the storm of passions which rushes down from intemperance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:35
verses.text: They also may be permitted to indulge in pleasantry at feasts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:36
verses.text: But to them also let the limit of their potations be the point up to which they keep their reason unwavering, their memory active, and their body unmoved and unshaken by wine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:37
verses.text: People in such a state are called by those who are skilful in these matters, acrothorakes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:38
verses.text: It is well, therefore, to leave off betimes, for fear of tripping.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:39
verses.text: One Artorius, in his book On Long Life (for so I remember), thinks that drink should be taken only till the food be moistened, that we may attain to a longer life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:40
verses.text: It is fitting, then, that some apply wine by way of physic, for the sake of health alone, and others for purposes of relaxation and enjoyment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:41
verses.text: For first wine makes the man who has drunk it more benignant than before, more agreeable to his boon companions, kinder to his domestics, and more pleasant to his friends.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:42
verses.text: But when intoxicated, he becomes violent instead.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:43
verses.text: For wine being warm, and having sweet juices when duly mixed, dissolves the foul excrementitious matters by its warmth, and mixes the acrid and base humours with the agreeable scents.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:44
verses.text: It has therefore been well said, "A joy of the soul and heart was wine created from the beginning, when drunk in moderate sufficiency".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:45
verses.text: And it is best to mix the wine with as much water as possible, and not to have recourse to it as to water, and so get enervated to drunkenness, and not pour it in as water from love of wine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:46
verses.text: For both are works of God; and so the mixture of both, of water and of wine, conduces together to health, because life consists of what is necessary and of what is useful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:47
verses.text: With water, then, which is the necessary of life, and to be used in abundance, there is also to be mixed the useful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:48
verses.text: By an immoderate quantity of wine the tongue is impeded; the lips are relaxed; the eyes roll wildly, the sight, as it were, swimming through the quantity of moisture; and compelled to deceive, they think that everything is revolving round them, and cannot count distant objects as single.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:49
verses.text: "And, in truth, methinks I see two suns," said the Theban old man in his cups.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:50
verses.text: For the sight, being disturbed by the heat of the wine, frequently fancies the substance of one object to be manifold.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:51
verses.text: And there is no difference between moving the eye or the object seen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:52
verses.text: For both have the same effect on the sight, which, on account of the fluctuation, cannot accurately obtain a perception of the object.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:53
verses.text: And the feet are carried from beneath the man as by a flood, and hiccuping and vomiting and maudlin nonsense follow; "for every intoxicated man," according to the tragedy,—  "Is conquered by anger, and empty of sense, And likes to pour forth much silly speech; And is wont to hear unwillingly, What evil words he with his will hath said".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:54
verses.text: And before tragedy, Wisdom cried, "Much wine drunk abounds in irritation and all manner of mistakes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:55
verses.text: Wherefore most people say that you ought to relax over your cups, and postpone serious business till morning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:56
verses.text: I however think that then especially ought reason to be introduced to mix in the feast, to act the part of director (paedagogue) to wine-drinking, lest conviviality imperceptibly degenerate to drunkenness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:57
verses.text: For as no sensible man ever thinks it requisite to shut his eyes before going to sleep, so neither can any one rightly wish reason to be absent from the festive board, or can well study to lull it asleep till business is begun.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:58
verses.text: But the Word can never quit those who belong to Him, not even if we are asleep; for He ought to be invited even to our sleep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:59
verses.text: For perfect wisdom, which is knowledge of things divine and human, which comprehends all that relates to the oversight of the flock of men, becomes, in reference to life, art; and so, while we live, is constantly, with us, always accomplishing its own proper work, the product of which is a good life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:60
verses.text: But the miserable wretches who expel temperance from conviviality, think excess in drinking to be the happiest life; and their life is nothing but revel, debauchery, baths, excess, urinals, idleness, drink.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:61
verses.text: You may see some of them, half-drunk, staggering, with crowns round their necks like wine jars, vomiting drink on one another in the name of good fellowship; and others, full of the effects of their debauch, dirty, pale in the face, livid, and still above yesterday's bout pouring another bout to last till next morning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:62
verses.text: It is well, my friends, it is well to make our acquaintance with this picture at the greatest possible distance from it, and to frame ourselves to what is better, dreading lest we also become a like spectacle and laughing-stock to others.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:63
verses.text: It has been appropriately said, "As the furnace proverb the steel blade in the process of dipping, so wine proveth the heart of the haughty".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:64
verses.text: A debauch is the immoderate use of wine, intoxication the disorder that results from such use; crapulousness (κραιπάλη) is the discomfort and nausea that follow a debauch; so called from the head shaking (κάρα πάλλειν).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:65
verses.text: Such a life as this (if life it must be called, which is spent in idleness, in agitation about voluptuous indulgences, and in the hallucinations of debauchery) the divine Wisdom looks on with contempt, and commands her children, "Be not a wine-bibber, nor spend your money in the purchase of flesh; for every drunkard and fornicator shall come to beggary, and every sluggard shall be clothed in tatters and rags".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:66
verses.text: For every one that is not awake to wisdom, but is steeped in wine, is a sluggard.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:67
verses.text: "And the drunkard," he says, "shall be clothed in rags, and be ashamed of his drunkenness in the presence of onlookers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:68
verses.text: For the wounds of the sinner are the rents of the garment of the flesh, the holes made by lusts, through which the shame of the soul within is seen—namely sin, by reason of which it will not be easy to save the garment, that has been torn away all round, that has rotted away in many lusts, and has been rent asunder from salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:69
verses.text: So he adds these most monitory words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:70
verses.text: "Who has woes, who has clamour, who has contentions, who has disgusting babblings, who has unavailing remorse?" You see, in all his raggedness, the lover of wine, who despises the Word Himself, and has abandoned and given himself to drunkenness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:71
verses.text: You see what threatening Scripture has pronounced against him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:72
verses.text: And to its threatening it adds again: "Whose are red eyes? Those, is it not, who tarry long at their wine, and hunt out the places where drinking goes on?" Here he shows the lover of drink to be already dead to the Word, by the mention of the bloodshot eyes,—a mark which appears on corpses, announcing to him death in the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:73
verses.text: For forgetfulness of the things which tend to true life turns the scale towards destruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:74
verses.text: With reason therefore, the Instructor, in His solicitude for our salvation, forbids us, "Drink not wine to drunkenness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:75
verses.text: Wherefore? you will ask.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:76
verses.text: Because, says He, "thy mouth will then speak perverse things, and thou liest down as in the heart of the sea, and as the steersman of a ship in the midst of huge billows".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:77
verses.text: Hence, too, poetry comes to our help, and says:—  "Let wine which has strength equal to fire come to men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:78
verses.text: Then will it agitate them, as the north or south wind agitates the Libyan waves".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:79
verses.text: And further:—  "Wine wandering in speech shows all secrets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:80
verses.text: Soul-deceiving wine is the ruin of those who drink it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:81
verses.text: And so on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:82
verses.text: You see the danger of shipwreck.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:83
verses.text: The heart is drowned in much drink.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:84
verses.text: The excess of drunkenness is compared to the danger of the sea, in which when the body has once been sunken like a ship, it descends to the depths of turpitude, overwhelmed in the mighty billows of wine; and the helmsman, the human mind, is tossed about on the surge of drunkenness, which swells aloft; and buried in the trough of the sea, is blinded by the darkness of the tempest, having drifted away from the haven of truth, till, dashing on the rocks beneath the sea, it perishes, driven by itself into voluptuous indulgences.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:85
verses.text: With reason, therefore, the apostle enjoins, "Be not drunk with wine, in which there is much excess;" by the term excess (ἀσωτία) intimating the inconsistence of drunkenness with salvation (τὸ ἄσωστον).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:86
verses.text: For if He made water wine at the marriage, He did not give permission to get drunk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:87
verses.text: He gave life to the watery element of the meaning of the law, filling with His blood the doer of it who is of Adam, that is, the whole world; supplying piety with drink from the vine of truth, the mixture of the old law and of the new word, in order to the fulfilment of the predestined time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:88
verses.text: The Scripture, accordingly, has named wine the symbol of the sacred blood; but reproving the base tippling with the dregs of wine, it says: "Intemperate is wine, and insolent is drunkenness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:89
verses.text: It is agreeable, therefore, to right reason, to drink on account of the cold of winter, till the numbness is dispelled from those who are subject to feel it; and on other occasions as a medicine for the intestines.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:90
verses.text: For, as we are to use food to satisfy hunger, so also are we to use drink to satisfy thirst, taking the most careful precautions against a slip: "for the introduction of wine is perilous".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:91
verses.text: And thus shall our soul be pure, and dry, and luminous; and the soul itself is wisest and best when dry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:92
verses.text: And thus, too, is it fit for contemplation, and is not humid with the exhalations, that rise from wine, forming a mass like a cloud.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:93
verses.text: We must not therefore trouble ourselves to procure Chian wine if it is absent, or Ariousian when it is not at hand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:94
verses.text: For thirst is a sensation of want, and craves means suitable for supplying the want, and not sumptuous liquor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:95
verses.text: Importations of wines from beyond seas are for an appetite enfeebled by excess, where the soul even before drunkenness is insane in its desires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:96
verses.text: For there are the fragrant Thasian wine, and the pleasant-breathing Lesbian, and a sweet Cretan wine, and sweet Syracusan wine, and Mendusian, an Egyptian wine, and the insular Naxian, the "highly perfumed and flavoured," another wine of the land of Italy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:97
verses.text: These are many names.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:98
verses.text: For the temperate drinker, one wine suffices, the product of the cultivation of the one God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:99
verses.text: For why should not the wine of their own country satisfy men's desires, unless they were to import water also, like the foolish Persian kings? The Choaspes, a river of India so called, was that from which the best water for drinking—the Choaspian—was got.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:100
verses.text: As wine, when taken, makes people lovers of it, so does water too.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:101
verses.text: The Holy Spirit, uttering His voice by Amos, pronounces the rich to be wretched on account of their luxury: "Those that drink strained wine, and recline on an ivory couch," he says; and what else similar he adds by way of reproach.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:102
verses.text: Especial regard is to be paid to decency (as the myth represents Athene, whoever she was, out of regard to it, giving up the pleasure of the flute because of the unseemliness of the sight): so that we are to drink without contortions of the face, not greedily grasping the cup, nor before drinking making the eyes roll with unseemly motion; nor from intemperance are we to drain the cup at a draught; nor besprinkle the chin, nor splash the garments while gulping down all the liquor at once,—our face all but filling the bowl, and drowned in it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:103
verses.text: For the gurgling occasioned by the drink rushing with violence, and by its being drawn in with a great deal of breath, as if it were being poured into an earthenware vessel, while the throat makes a noise through the rapidity of ingurgitation, is a shameful and unseemly spectacle of intemperance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:104
verses.text: In addition to this, eagerness in drinking is a practice injurious to the partaker.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:105
verses.text: Do not haste to mischief, my friend.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:106
verses.text: Your drink is not being taken from you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:107
verses.text: It is given you, and waits you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:108
verses.text: Be not eager to burst, by draining it down with gaping throat.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:109
verses.text: Your thirst is satiated, even if you drink slower, observing decorum, by taking the beverage in small portions, in an orderly way.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:110
verses.text: For that which intemperance greedily seizes, is not taken away by taking time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:111
verses.text: "Be not mighty," he says, "at wine; for wine has overcome many".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:112
verses.text: The Scythians, the Celts, the Iberians, and the Thracians, all of them warlike races, are greatly addicted to intoxication, and think that it is an honourable, happy pursuit to engage in.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:113
verses.text: But we, the people of peace, feasting for lawful enjoyment, not to wantonness, drink sober cups of friendship, that our friendships may be shown in a way truly appropriate to the name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:114
verses.text: In what manner do you think the Lord drank when He became man for our sakes? As shamelessly as we? Was it not with decorum and propriety? Was it not deliberately? For rest assured, He Himself also partook of wine; for He, too, was man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:115
verses.text: And He blessed the wine, saying, "Take, drink: this is my blood"—the blood of the vine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:116
verses.text: He figuratively calls the Word "shed for many, for the remission of sins"—the holy stream of gladness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:117
verses.text: And that he who drinks ought to observe moderation, He clearly showed by what He taught at feasts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:118
verses.text: For He did not teach affected by wine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:119
verses.text: And that it was wine which was the thing blessed, He showed again, when He said to His disciples, "I will not drink of the fruit of this vine, till I drink it with you in the kingdom of my Father".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:120
verses.text: But that it was wine which was drunk by the Lord, He tells us again, when He spake concerning Himself, reproaching the Jews for their hardness of heart: "For the Son of man," He says, "came, and they say, Behold a glutton and a wine-bibber, a friend of publicans".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:121
verses.text: Let this be held fast by us against those that are called Encratites.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:122
verses.text: But women, making a profession, forsooth, of aiming at the graceful, that their lips may not be rent apart by stretching them on broad drinking cups, and so widening the mouth, drinking in an unseemly way out of alabastra quite too narrow: in the mouth, throw back their heads and bare their necks indecently, as I think; and distending the throat in swallowing, gulp down the liquor as if to make bare all they can to their boon companions; and drawing hiccups like men, or rather like slaves, revel in luxurious riot.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:123
verses.text: For nothing disgraceful is proper for man, who is endowed with reason; much less for woman to whom it brings modesty even to reflect of what nature she is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:124
verses.text: "An intoxicated woman is great wrath," it is said, as if a drunken woman were the wrath of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:125
verses.text: Why? "Because she will not conceal her shame".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:126
verses.text: For a woman is quickly drawn down to licentiousness, if she only set her choice on pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:127
verses.text: And we have not prohibited drinking from alabastra; but we forbid studying to drink from them alone, as arrogant; counselling women to use with indifference what comes in the way, and cutting up by the roots the dangerous appetites that are in them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:128
verses.text: Let the rush of air, then, which regurgitates so as to produce hiccup, be emitted silently.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:129
verses.text: But by no manner of means are women to be allotted to uncover and exhibit any part of their person, lest both fall,—the men by being excited to look, they by drawing on themselves the eyes of the men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:130
verses.text: But always must we conduct ourselves as in the Lord's presence, lest He say to us, as the apostle in indignation said to the Corinthians, "When ye come together, this is not to eat the Lord's supper".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:131
verses.text: To me, the star called by the mathematicians Acephalus (headless), which is numbered before the wandering star, his head resting on his breast, seems to be a type of the gluttonous, the voluptuous, and those that are prone to drunkenness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:132
verses.text: For in such the faculty of reasoning is not situated in the head, but among the intestinal appetites, enslaved to lust and anger.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:133
verses.text: For just as Elpenor broke his neck through intoxication, so the brain, dizzied by drunkenness, falls down from above, with a great fall to the liver and the heart, that is, to voluptuousness and anger: as the sons of the poets say Hephaestus was hurled by Zeus from heaven to earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:134
verses.text: "The trouble of sleeplessness, and bile, and cholic, are with an insatiable man," it is said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:135
verses.text: Wherefore also Noah's intoxication was recorded in writing, that, with the clear and written description of his transgression before us, we might guard with all our might against drunkenness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:136
verses.text: For which cause they who covered the shame of his drunkenness are blessed by the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 3:137
verses.text: The Scripture accordingly, giving a most comprehensive compend, has expressed all in one word: "To an instructed man sufficiency is wine, and he will rest in his bed".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 3—On Costly Vessels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:2
verses.text: And so the use of cups made of silver and gold, and of others inlaid with precious stones, is out of place, being only a deception of the vision.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:3
verses.text: For if you pour any warm liquid into them, the vessels becoming hot, to touch them is painful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:4
verses.text: On the other hand, if you pour in what is cold, the material changes its quality, injuring the mixture, and the rich potion is hurtful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:5
verses.text: Away, then, with Thericleian cups and Antigonides, and Canthari, and goblets, and Lepastae, and the endless shapes of drinking vessels, and wine-coolers, and wine-pourers also.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:6
verses.text: For, on the whole, gold and silver, both publicly and privately, are an invidious possession when they exceed what is necessary, seldom to be acquired, difficult to keep, and not adapted for use.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:7
verses.text: The elaborate vanity, too, of vessels in glass chased, more apt to break on account of the art, teaching us to fear while we drink, is to be banished from our well-ordered constitution.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:8
verses.text: And silver couches, and pans and vinegar-saucers, and trenchers and bowls; and besides these, vessels of silver and gold, some for serving food, and others for other uses which I am ashamed to name, of easily cleft cedar and thyine wood, and ebony, and tripods fashioned of ivory, and couches with silver feet and inlaid with ivory, and folding-doors of beds studded with gold and variegated with tortoise-shell, and bed-clothes of purple and other colours difficult to produce, proofs of tasteless luxury, cunning devices of envy and effeminacy,—are all to be relinquished, as having nothing whatever worth our pains.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:9
verses.text: "For the time is short," as says the apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:10
verses.text: This then remains that we do not make a ridiculous figure, as some are seen in the public spectacles outwardly anointed strikingly for imposing effect, but wretched within.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:11
verses.text: Explaining this more clearly, he adds, "It remains that they that have wives be as though they had none, and they that buy as though they possessed not".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:12
verses.text: And if he speaks thus of marriage, in reference to which God says, "Multiply," how do you not think that senseless display is by the Lord's authority to be banished? Wherefore also the Lord says, "Sell what thou hast, and give to the poor; and come, follow me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:13
verses.text: Follow God, stripped of arrogance, stripped of fading display, possessed of that which is thine, which is good, what alone cannot be taken away—faith towards God, confession towards Him who suffered, beneficence towards men, which is the most precious of possessions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:14
verses.text: For my part, I approve of Plato, who plainly lays it down as a law, that a man is not to labour for wealth of gold or silver, nor to possess a useless vessel which is not for some necessary purpose, and moderate; so that the same thing may serve for many purposes, and the possession of a variety of things may be done away with.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:15
verses.text: Excellently, therefore, the Divine Scripture, addressing boasters and lovers of their own selves, says, "Where are the rulers of the nations, and the lords of the wild beasts of the earth, who sport among the birds of heaven, who treasured up silver and gold, in whom men trusted, and there was no end of their substance, who fashioned silver and gold, and were full of care? There is no finding of their works.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:16
verses.text: They have vanished, and gone down to Hades".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:17
verses.text: Such is the reward of display.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:18
verses.text: For though such of us as cultivate the soil need a mattock and plough, none of us will make a pickaxe of silver or a sickle of gold, but we employ the material which is serviceable for agriculture, not what is costly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:19
verses.text: What prevents those who are capable of considering what is similar from entertaining the same sentiments with respect to household utensils, of which let use, not expense, be the measure? For tell me, does the table-knife not cut unless it be studded with silver, and have its handle made of ivory? Or must we forge Indian steel in order to divide meat, as when we call for a weapon for the fight? What if the basin be of earthenware? will it not receive the dirt of the hands? or the footpan the dirt of the foot? Will the table that is fashioned with ivory feet be indignant at bearing a three-halfpenny loaf? Will the lamp not dispense light because it is the work of the potter, not of the goldsmith? I affirm that truckle-beds afford no worse repose than the ivory couch; and the goatskin coverlet being amply sufficient to spread on the bed, there is no need of purple or scarlet coverings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:20
verses.text: Yet to condemn, notwithstanding, frugality, through the stupidity of luxury, the author of mischief, what a prodigious error, what senseless conceit! See.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:21
verses.text: The Lord ate from a common bowl, and made the disciples recline on the grass on the ground, and washed their feet, girded with a linen towel—He, the lowly-minded God, and Lord of the universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:22
verses.text: He did not bring down a silver foot-bath from heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:23
verses.text: He asked to drink of the Samaritan woman, who drew the water from the well in an earthenware vessel, not seeking regal gold, but teaching us how to quench thirst easily.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:24
verses.text: For He made use, not extravagance His aim.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:25
