verses.text: And He ate and drank at feasts, not digging metals from the earth, nor using vessels of gold and silver, that is, vessels exhaling the odour of rust—such fumes as the rust of smoking metal gives off.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:26
verses.text: For in fine, in food, and clothes, and vessels, and everything else belonging to the house, I say comprehensively, that one must follow the institutions of the Christian man, as is serviceable and suitable to one's person, age, pursuits, time of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:27
verses.text: For it becomes those that are servants of one God, that their possessions and furniture should exhibit the tokens of one beautiful life; and that each individually should be seen in faith, which shows no difference, practising all other things which are conformable to this uniform mode of life, and harmonious with this one scheme.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:28
verses.text: What we acquire without difficulty, and use with ease, we praise, keep easily, and communicate freely.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:29
verses.text: The things which are useful are preferable, and consequently cheap things are better than dear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:30
verses.text: In fine, wealth, when not properly governed, is a stronghold of evil, about which many casting their eyes, they will never reach the kingdom of heaven, sick for the things of the world, and living proudly through luxury.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:31
verses.text: But those who are in earnest about salvation must settle this beforehand in their mind, "that all that we possess is given to us for use, and use for sufficiency, which one may attain to by a few things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:32
verses.text: For silly are they who, from greed, take delight in what they have hoarded up.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:33
verses.text: "He that gathereth wages," it is said, "gathereth into a bag with holes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:34
verses.text: Such is he who gathers corn and shuts it up; and he who giveth to no one, becomes poorer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:35
verses.text: It is a farce, and a thing to make one laugh outright, for men to bring in silver urinals and crystal vases de nuit, as they usher in their counsellors, and for silly rich women to get gold receptacles for excrements made; so that being rich, they cannot even ease themselves except in superb way.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:36
verses.text: I would that in their whole life they deemed gold fit for dung.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:37
verses.text: But now love of money is found to be the stronghold of evil, which the apostle says "is the root of all evils, which, while some coveted, they have erred from the faith, and pierced themselves through with many sorrows".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:38
verses.text: But the best riches is poverty of desires; and the true magnanimity is not to be proud of wealth, but to despise it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:39
verses.text: Boasting about one's plate is utterly base.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:40
verses.text: For it is plainly wrong to care much about what any one who likes may buy from the market.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:41
verses.text: But wisdom is not bought with coin of earth, nor is it sold in the market-place, but in heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 4:42
verses.text: And it is sold for true coin, the immortal Word, the regal gold.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 4—How to Conduct Ourselves at Feasts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:2
verses.text: Let revelry keep away from our rational entertainments, and foolish vigils, too, that revel in intemperance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:3
verses.text: For revelry is an inebriating pipe, the chain of an amatory bridge, that is, of sorrow.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:4
verses.text: And let love, and intoxication, and senseless passions, be removed from our choir.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:5
verses.text: Burlesque singing is the boon companion of drunkenness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:6
verses.text: A night spent over drink invites drunkenness, rouses lust, and is audacious in deeds of shame.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:7
verses.text: For if people occupy their time with pipes, and psalteries, and choirs, and dances, and Egyptian clapping of hands, and such disorderly frivolities, they become quite immodest and intractable, beat on cymbals and drums, and make a noise on instruments of delusion; for plainly such a banquet, as seems to me, is a theatre of drunkenness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:8
verses.text: For the apostle decrees that, "putting off the works of darkness, we should put on the armour of light, walking honestly as in the day, not spending our time in rioting and drunkenness, in chambering and wantonness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:9
verses.text: Let the pipe be resigned to the shepherds, and the flute to the superstitious who are engrossed in idolatry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:10
verses.text: For, in truth, such instruments are to be banished from the temperate banquet, being more suitable to beasts than men, and the more irrational portion of mankind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:11
verses.text: For we have heard of stags being charmed by the pipe, and seduced by music into the toils, when hunted by the huntsmen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:12
verses.text: And when mares are being covered, a tune is played on the flute—a nuptial song, as it were.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:13
verses.text: And every improper sight and sound, to speak in a word, and every shameful sensation of licentiousnes—which, in truth, is privation of sensation—must by all means be excluded; and we must be on our guard against whatever pleasure titillates eye and ear, and effeminates.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:14
verses.text: For the various spells of the broken strains and plaintive numbers of the Carian muse corrupt men's morals, drawing to perturbation of mind, by the licentious and mischievous art of music.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:15
verses.text: The Spirit, distinguishing from such revelry the divine service, sings, "Praise Him with the sound of trumpet;" for with sound of trumpet He shall raise the dead.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:16
verses.text: "Praise Him on the psaltery;" for the tongue is the psaltery of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:17
verses.text: "And praise Him on the lyre".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:18
verses.text: By the lyre is meant the mouth struck by the Spirit, as it were by a plectrum.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:19
verses.text: "Praise with the timbrel and the dance," refers to the Church meditating on the resurrection of the dead in the resounding skin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:20
verses.text: "Praise Him on the chords and organ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:21
verses.text: Our body He calls an organ, and its nerves are the strings, by which it has received harmonious tension, and when struck by the Spirit, it gives forth human voices.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:22
verses.text: "Praise Him on the clashing cymbals".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:23
verses.text: He calls the tongue the cymbal of the mouth, which resounds with the pulsation of the lips.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:24
verses.text: Therefore He cried to humanity, "Let every breath praise the Lord," because He cares for every breathing thing which He hath made.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:25
verses.text: For man is truly a pacific instrument; while other instruments, if you investigate, you will find to be warlike, inflaming to lusts, or kindling up amours, or rousing wrath.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:26
verses.text: In their wars, therefore, the Etruscans use the trumpet, the Arcadians the pipe, the Sicilians the pectides, the Cretans the lyre, the Lacedaemonians the flute, the Thracians the horn, the Egyptians the drum, and the Arabians the cymbal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:27
verses.text: The one instrument of peace, the Word alone by which we honour God, is what we employ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:28
verses.text: We no longer employ the ancient psaltery, and trumpet, and timbrel, and flute, which those expert in war and contemners of the fear of God were wont to make use of also in the choruses at their festive assemblies; that by such strains they might raise their dejected minds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:29
verses.text: But let our genial feeling in drinking be twofold, in accordance with the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:30
verses.text: For "if thou shalt love the Lord thy God," and then "thy neighbour," let its first manifestation be towards God in thanksgiving and psalmody, and the second toward our neighbour in decorous fellowship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:31
verses.text: For says the apostle, "Let the Word of the Lord dwell in you richly".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:32
verses.text: And this Word suits and conforms Himself to seasons, to persons, to places.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:33
verses.text: In the present instance He is a guest with us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:34
verses.text: For the apostle adds again, "Teaching and admonishing one another in all wisdom, in psalms, and hymns, and spiritual songs, singing with grace in your heart to God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:35
verses.text: And again, "Whatsoever ye do in word or deed, do all in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God and His Father".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:36
verses.text: This is our thankful revelry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:37
verses.text: And even if you wish to sing and play to the harp or lyre, there is no blame.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:38
verses.text: Thou shalt imitate the righteous Hebrew king in his thanksgiving to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:39
verses.text: "Rejoice in the Lord, ye righteous; praise is comely to the upright," says the prophecy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:40
verses.text: "Confess to the Lord on the harp; play to Him on the psaltery of ten strings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:41
verses.text: Sing to Him a new song".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:42
verses.text: And does not the ten-stringed psaltery indicate the Word Jesus, who is manifested by the element of the decad? And as it is befitting, before partaking of food, that we should bless the Creator of all; so also in drinking it is suitable to praise Him on partaking of His creatures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:43
verses.text: For the psalm is a melodious and sober blessing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:44
verses.text: The apostle calls the psalm "a spiritual song".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:45
verses.text: Finally, before partaking of sleep, it is a sacred duty to give thanks to God, having enjoyed His grace and love, and so go straight to sleep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:46
verses.text: "And confess to Him in songs of the lips," he says, "because in His command all His good pleasure is done, and there is no deficiency in His salvation".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:47
verses.text: Further, among the ancient Greeks, in their banquets over the brimming cups, a song was sung called a skolion, after the manner of the Hebrew psalms, all together raising the paean with the voice, and sometimes also taking turns in the song while they drank healths round; while those that were more musical than the rest sang to the lyre.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:48
verses.text: But let amatory songs be banished far away, and let our songs be hymns to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:49
verses.text: "Let them praise," it is said, "His name in the dance, and let them play to Him on the timbrel and psaltery".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:50
verses.text: And what is the choir which plays? The Spirit will show thee: "Let His praise be in the congregation (church) of the saints; let them be joyful in their King".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:51
verses.text: And again he adds, "The Lord will take pleasure in His people".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:52
verses.text: For temperate harmonies are to be admitted; but we are to banish as far as possible from our robust mind those liquid harmonies, which, through pernicious arts in the modulations of tones, train to effeminacy and scurrility.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:53
verses.text: But grave and modest strains say farewell to the turbulence of drunkenness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 5:54
verses.text: Chromatic harmonies are therefore to be abandoned to immodest revels, and to florid and meretricious music.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 5—On Laughter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:2
verses.text: People who are imitators of ludicrous sensations, or rather of such as deserve derision, are to be driven from our polity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:3
verses.text: For since all forms of speech flow from mind and manners, ludicrous expressions could not be uttered, did they not proceed from ludicrous practices.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:4
verses.text: For the saying, "It is not a good tree which produces corrupt fruit, nor a corrupt tree which produces good fruit," is to be applied in this case.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:5
verses.text: For speech is the fruit of the mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:6
verses.text: If, then, wags are to be ejected from our society, we ourselves must by no manner of means be allowed to stir up laughter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:7
verses.text: For it were absurd to be found imitators of things of which we are prohibited to be listeners; and still more absurd for a man to set about making himself a laughing-stock, that is, the butt of insult and derision.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:8
verses.text: For if we could not endure to make a ridiculous figure, such as we see some do in processions, how could we with any propriety bear to have the inner man made a ridiculous figure of, and that to one's face? Wherefore we ought never of our own accord to assume a ludicrous character.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:9
verses.text: And how, then, can we devote ourselves to being and appearing ridiculous in our conversation, thereby travestying speech, which is the most precious of all human endowments? It is therefore disgraceful to set one's self to do this; since the conversation of wags of this description is not fit for our ears, inasmuch as by the very expressions used it familiarizes us with shameful actions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:10
verses.text: Pleasantry is allowable, not waggery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:11
verses.text: Besides, even laughter must be kept in check; for when given vent to in the right manner it indicates orderliness, but when it issues differently it shows a want of restraint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:12
verses.text: For, in a word, whatever things are natural to men we must not eradicate from them, but rather impose on them limits and suitable times.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:13
verses.text: For man is not to laugh on all occasions because he is a laughing animal, any more than the horse neighs on all occasions because he is a neighing animal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:14
verses.text: But as rational beings, we are to regulate ourselves suitably, harmoniously relaxing the austerity and over-tension of our serious pursuits, not inharmoniously breaking them up altogether.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:15
verses.text: For the seemly relaxation of the countenance in a harmonious manner—as of a musical instrument—is called a smile.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:16
verses.text: So also is laughter on the face of well-regulated men termed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:17
verses.text: But the discordant relaxation of countenance in the case of women is called a giggle, and is meretricious laughter; in the case of men, a guffaw, and is savage and insulting laughter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:18
verses.text: "A fool raises his voice in laughter," says the Scripture; but a clever man smiles almost imperceptibly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:19
verses.text: The clever man in this case he calls wise, inasmuch as he is differently affected from the fool.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:20
verses.text: But, on the other hand, one needs not be gloomy, only grave.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:21
verses.text: For I certainly prefer a man to smile who has a stern countenance than the reverse; for so his laughter will be less apt to become the object of ridicule.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:22
verses.text: Smiling even requires to be made the subject of discipline.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:23
verses.text: If it is at what is disgraceful, we ought to blush rather than smile, lest we seem to take pleasure in it by sympathy; if at what is painful, it is fitting to look sad rather than to seem pleased.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:24
verses.text: For to do the former is a sign of rational human thought; the other infers suspicion of cruelty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:25
verses.text: We are not to laugh perpetually, for that is going beyond bounds; nor in the presence of elderly persons, or others worthy of respect, unless they indulge in pleasantry for our amusement.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:26
verses.text: Nor are we to laugh before all and sundry, nor in every place, nor to every one, nor about everything.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:27
verses.text: For to children and women especially laughter is the cause of slipping into scandal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:28
verses.text: And even to appear stern serves to keep those about us at their distance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:29
verses.text: For gravity can ward off the approaches of licentiousness by a mere look.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:30
verses.text: All senseless people, to speak in a word, wine  "Commands both to laugh luxuriously and to dance,"  changing effeminate manners to softness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:31
verses.text: We must consider, too, how consequently freedom of speech leads impropriety on to filthy speaking.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:32
verses.text: "And he uttered a word which had been better unsaid".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 6:33
verses.text: Especially, therefore, in liquor crafty men's characters are wont to be seen through, stripped as they are of their mask through the caitiff licence of intoxication, through which reason, weighed down in the soul itself by drunkenness, is lulled to sleep, and unruly passions are roused, which overmaster the feebleness of the mind.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 6—On Filthy Speaking.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:2
verses.text: From filthy speaking we ourselves must entirely abstain, and stop the mouths of those who practice it by stern looks and averting the face, and by what we call making a mock of one: often also by a harsher mode of speech.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:3
verses.text: "For what proceedeth out of the mouth," He says, "defileth a man,"—shows him to be unclean, and heathenish, and untrained, and licentious, and not select, and proper, and honourable, and temperate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:4
verses.text: And as a similar rule holds with regard to hearing and seeing in the case of what is obscene, the divine Instructor, following the same course with both, arrays those children who are engaged in the struggle in words of modesty, as ear-guards, so that the pulsation of fornication may not penetrate to the bruising of the soul; and He directs the eyes to the sight of what is honourable, saying that it is better to make a slip with the feet than with the eyes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:5
verses.text: This filthy speaking the apostle beats off, saying, "Let no corrupt communication proceed out of your mouth, but what is good".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:6
verses.text: And again, "As becometh saints, let not filthiness be named among you, nor foolish talking, nor jesting, which things are not seemly, but rather giving of thanks".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:7
verses.text: And if "he that calls his brother a fool be in danger of the judgment," what shall we pronounce regarding him who speaks what is foolish? Is it not written respecting such: "Whosoever shall speak an idle word, shall give an account to the Lord in the day of judgment?" And again, "By thy speech thou shalt be justified," He says, "and by thy speech thou shalt be condemned".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:8
verses.text: What, then, are the salutary ear-guards, and what the regulations for slippery eyes? Conversations with the righteous, preoccupying and forearming the ears against those that would lead away from the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:9
verses.text: "Evil communications corrupt good manners,"  says Poetry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:10
verses.text: More nobly the apostle says, "Be haters of the evil; cleave to the good".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:11
verses.text: For he who associates with the saints shall be sanctified.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:12
verses.text: From shameful things addressed to the ears, and words and sights, we must entirely abstain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:13
verses.text: And much more must we keep pure from shameful deeds: on the one hand, from exhibiting and exposing parts of the body which we ought not; and on the other, from beholding what is forbidden.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:14
verses.text: For the modest son could not bear to look on the shameful exposure of the righteous man; and modesty covered what intoxication exposed—the spectacle of the transgression of ignorance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:15
verses.text: No less ought we to keep pure from calumnious reports, to which the ears of those who have believed in Christ ought to be inaccessible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:16
verses.text: It is on this account, as appears to me, that the Instructor does not permit us to give utterance to aught unseemly, fortifying us at an early stage against licentiousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:17
verses.text: For He is admirable always at cutting out the roots of sins, such as, "Thou shalt not commit adultery," by "Thou shalt not lust".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:18
verses.text: For adultery is the fruit of lust, which is the evil root.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:19
verses.text: And so likewise also in this instance the Instructor censures licence in names, and thus cuts off the licentious intercourse of excess.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:20
verses.text: For licence in names produces the desire of being indecorous in conduct; and the observance of modesty in names is a training in resistance to lasciviousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:21
verses.text: We have shown in a more exhaustive treatise, that neither in the names nor in the members to which appellations not in common use are applied, is there the designation of what is really obscene.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:22
verses.text: For neither are knee and leg, and such other members, nor are the names applied to them, and the activity put forth by them, obscene.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:23
verses.text: And even the pudenda are to be regarded as objects suggestive of modesty, not shame.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:24
verses.text: It is their unlawful activity that is shameful, and deserving ignominy, and reproach, and punishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:25
verses.text: For the only thing that is in reality shameful is wickedness, and what is done through it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:26
verses.text: In accordance with these remarks, conversation about deeds of wickedness is appropriately termed filthy shameful speaking, as talk about adultery and paederasty and the like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:27
verses.text: Frivolous prating, too, is to be put to silence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:28
verses.text: "For," it is said, "in much speaking thou shalt not escape sin".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:29
verses.text: "Sins of the tongue, therefore, shall be punished".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:30
verses.text: "There is he who is silent, and is found wise; and there is he that is hated for much speech".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:31
verses.text: But still more, the prater makes himself the object of disgust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 7:32
verses.text: "For he that multiplieth speech abominates his own soul".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 7—Directions for Those Who Live Together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:2
verses.text: Let us keep away from us jibing, the originator of insult, from which strifes and contentions and enmities burst forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:3
verses.text: Insult, we have said, is the servant of drunkenness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:4
verses.text: A man is judged, not from his deeds alone, but from his words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:5
verses.text: "In a banquet," it is said, "reprove not thy neighbour, nor say to him a word of reproach".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:6
verses.text: For if we are enjoined especially to associate with saints, it is a sin to jibe at a saint: "For from the mouth of the foolish," says the Scripture, "is a staff of insult,"—meaning by staff the prop of insult, on which insult leans and rests.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:7
verses.text: Whence I admire the apostle, who, in reference to this, exhorts us not to utter "scurrilous nor unsuitable words".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:8
verses.text: For if the assemblies at festivals take place on account of affection, and the end of a banquet is friendliness towards those who meet, and meat and drink accompany affection, how should not conversation be conducted in a rational manner, and puzzling people with questions be avoided from affection? For if we meet together for the purpose of increasing our good-will to each other, why should we stir up enmity by jibing? It is better to be silent than to contradict, and thereby add sin to ignorance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:9
verses.text: "Blessed," in truth, "is the man who has not made a slip with his mouth, and has not been pierced by the pain of sin;" or has repented of what he has said amiss, or has spoken so as to wound no one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:10
verses.text: On the whole, let young men and young women altogether keep away from such festivals, that they may not make a slip in respect to what is unsuitable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:11
verses.text: For things to which their ears are unaccustomed, and unseemly sights, inflame the mind, while faith within them is still wavering; and the instability of their age conspires to make them easily carried away by lust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:12
verses.text: Sometimes also they are the cause of others stumbling, by displaying the dangerous charms of their time of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:13
verses.text: For Wisdom appears to enjoin well: "Sit not at all with a married woman, and recline not on the elbow with her;" that is, do not sup nor eat with her frequently.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:14
verses.text: Wherefore he adds, "And do not join company with her in wine, lest thy heart incline to her, and by thy blood slide to ruin".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:15
verses.text: For the licence of intoxication is dangerous, and prone to deflower.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:16
verses.text: And he names "a married woman," because the danger is greater to him who attempts to break the connubial bond.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:17
verses.text: But if any necessity arises, commanding the presence of married women, let them be well clothed—without by raiment, within by modesty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:18
verses.text: But as for such as are unmarried, it is the extremest scandal for them to be present at a banquet of men, especially men under the influence of wine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:19
verses.text: And let the men, fixing their eyes on the couch, and leaning without moving on their elbows, be present with their ears alone; and if they sit, let them not have their feet crossed, nor place one thigh on another, nor apply the hand to the chin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:20
verses.text: For it is vulgar not to bear one's self without support, and consequently a fault in a young man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:21
verses.text: And perpetually moving and changing one's position is a sign of frivolousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:22
verses.text: It is the part of a temperate man also, in eating and drinking, to take a small portion, and deliberately, not eagerly, both at the beginning and during the courses, and to leave off betimes, and so show his indifference.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:23
verses.text: "Eat," it is said, "like a man what is set before you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:24
verses.text: Be the first to stop for the sake of regimen; and, if seated in the midst of several people, do not stretch out your hand before them".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:25
verses.text: You must never rush forward under the influence of gluttony; nor must you, though desirous, reach out your hand till some time, inasmuch as by greed one shows an uncontrolled appetite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:26
verses.text: Nor are you, in the midst of the repast, to exhibit yourselves hugging your food like wild beasts; nor helping yourselves to too much sauce, for man is not by nature a sauce-consumer, but a bread-eater.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:27
verses.text: A temperate man, too, must rise before the general company, and retire quietly from the banquet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:28
verses.text: "For at the time for rising," it is said, "be not the last; haste home".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:29
verses.text: The twelve, having called together the multitude of the disciples, said, "It is not meet for us to leave the word of God and serve tables".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:30
verses.text: If they avoided this, much more did they shun gluttony.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:31
verses.text: And the apostles themselves, writing to the brethren at Antioch, and in Syria and Cilicia, said: "It seemed good to the Holy Ghost, and to us, to lay upon you no other burden than these necessary things, to abstain from things offered to idols, and from blood, and from things strangled, and from fornication, from which, if you keep yourselves, ye shall do well".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:32
verses.text: But we must guard against drunkenness as against hemlock; for both drag down to death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:33
verses.text: We must also check excessive laughter and immoderate tears.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:34
verses.text: For often people under the influence of wine, after laughing immoderately, then are, I know not how, by some impulse of intoxication moved to tears; for both effiminacy and violence are discordant with the word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:35
verses.text: And elderly people, looking on the young as children, may, though but very rarely, be playful with them, joking with them to train them in good behaviour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:36
verses.text: For example, before a bashful and silent youth, one might by way of pleasantry speak thus: "This son of mine (I mean one who is silent) is perpetually talking".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:37
verses.text: For a joke such as this enhances the youth's modesty, by showing the good qualities that belong to him playfully, by censure of the bad quantities, which do not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:38
verses.text: For this device is instructive, confirming as it does what is present by what is not present.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:39
verses.text: Such, certainly, is the intention of him who says that a water-drinker and a sober man gets intoxicated and drunk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:40
verses.text: But if there are those who like to jest at people, we must be silent, and dispense with superfluous words like full cups.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:41
verses.text: For such sport is dangerous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:42
verses.text: "The mouth of the impetuous approaches to contrition".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:43
verses.text: "Thou shalt not receive a foolish report, nor shall thou agree with an unjust person to be an unjust witness," neither in calumnies nor in injurious speeches, much less evil practices.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:44
verses.text: I also should think it right to impose a limit on the speech of rightly regulated persons, who are impelled to speak to one who maintains a conversation with them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:45
verses.text: "For silence is the excellence of women, and the safe prize of the young; but good speech is characteristic of experienced, mature age.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:46
verses.text: Speak, old man, at a banquet, for it is becoming to you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:47
verses.text: But speak without embarrassment, and with accuracy of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:48
verses.text: Youth, Wisdom also commands thee.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:49
verses.text: Speak, if you must, with hesitation, on being twice asked; sum up your discourse in a few words".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:50
verses.text: But let both speakers regulate their discourse according to just proportion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:51
verses.text: For loudness of utterance is most insane; while an inaudible utterance is characteristic of a senseless man, for people will not hear: the one is the mark of pusillanimity, the other of arrogance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:52
verses.text: Let contentiousness in words, for the sake of a useless triumph, be banished; for our aim is to be free from perturbation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:53
verses.text: Such is the meaning of the phrase, "Peace to thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:54
verses.text: Answer not a word before you hear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:55
verses.text: An enervated voice is the sign of effeminacy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:56
verses.text: But modulation in the voice is characteristic of a wise man, who keeps his utterance from loudness, from drawling, from rapidity, from prolixity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:57
verses.text: For we ought not to speak long or much, nor ought we to speak frivolously.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:58
verses.text: Nor must we converse rapidly and rashly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:59
verses.text: For the voice itself, so to speak, ought to receive its just dues; and those who are vociferous and clamorous ought to be silenced.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:60
verses.text: For this reason, the wise Ulysses chastised Thersites with stripes:—  "Only Thersites, with unmeasured words, Of which he had good store, to rate the chiefs, Not over-seemly, but wherewith he thought To move the crowd to laughter, brawled aloud".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:61
verses.text: "For dreadful in his destruction is a loquacious man".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:62
verses.text: And it is with triflers as with old shoes: all the rest is worn away by evil; the tongue only is left for destruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:63
verses.text: Wherefore Wisdom gives these most useful exhortations: "Do not talk trifles in the multitude of the elders".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:64
verses.text: Further, eradicating frivolousness, beginning with God, it lays down the law for our regulation somewhat thus: "Do not repeat your words in your prayer".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:65
verses.text: Chirruping and whistling, and sounds made through the fingers, by which domestics are called, being irrational signs, are to be given up by rational men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:66
verses.text: Frequent spitting, too, and violent clearing of the throat, and wiping one's nose at an entertainment, are to be shunned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:67
verses.text: For respect is assuredly to be had to the guests, lest they turn in disgust from such filthiness, which argues want of restraint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:68
verses.text: For we are not to copy oxen and asses, whose manger and dunghill are together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:69
verses.text: For many wipe their noses and spit even whilst supping.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:70
verses.text: If any one is attacked with sneezing, just as in the case of hiccup, he must not startle those near him with the explosion, and so give proof of his bad breeding; but the hiccup is to be quietly transmitted with the expiration of the breath, the mouth being composed becomingly, and not gaping and yawning like the tragic masks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:71
verses.text: So the disturbance of hiccup may be avoided by making the respirations gently; for thus the threatening symptoms of the ball of wind will be dissipated in the most seemly way, by managing its egress so as also to conceal anything which the air forcibly expelled may bring up with it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:72
verses.text: To wish to add to the noises, instead of diminishing them, is the sign of arrogance and disorderliness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:73
verses.text: Those, too, who scrape their teeth, bleeding the wounds, are disagreeable to themselves and detestable to their neighbours.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:74
verses.text: Scratching the ears and the irritation of sneezing are swinish itchings, and attend unbridled fornication.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:75
verses.text: Both shameful sights and shameful conversation about them are to be shunned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:76
verses.text: Let the look be steady, and the turning and movement of the neck, and the motions of the hands in conversation, be decorous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 8:77
verses.text: In a word, the Christian is characterized by composure, tranquillity, calmness, and peace.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—On the Use of Ointments and Crowns.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:2
verses.text: The use of crowns and ointments is not necessary for us; for it impels to pleasures and indulgences, especially on the approach of night.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:3
verses.text: I know that the woman brought to the sacred supper "an alabaster box of ointment," and anointed the feet of the Lord, and refreshed Him; and I know that the ancient kings of the Hebrews were crowned with gold and precious stones.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:4
verses.text: But the woman not having yet received the Word (for she was still a sinner), honoured the Lord with what she thought the most precious thing in her possession—the ointment; and with the ornament of her person, with her hair, she wiped off the superfluous ointment, while she expended on the Lord tears of repentance: "wherefore her sins are forgiven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:5
verses.text: This may be a symbol of the Lord's teaching, and of His suffering.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:6
verses.text: For the feet anointed with fragrant ointment mean divine instruction travelling with renown to the ends of the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:7
verses.text: "For their sound hath gone forth to the ends of the earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:8
verses.text: And if I seem not to insist too much, the feet of the Lord which were anointed are the apostles, having, according to prophecy, received the fragrant unction of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:9
verses.text: Those, therefore, who travelled over the world and preached the Gospel, are figuratively called the feet of the Lord, of whom also the Holy Spirit foretells in the psalm, "Let us adore at the place where His feet stood," that is, where the apostles, His feet, arrived; since, preached by them, He came to the ends of the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:10
verses.text: And tears are repentance; and the loosened hair proclaimed deliverance from the love of finery, and the affliction in patience which, on account of the Lord, attends preaching, the old vainglory being done away with by reason of the new faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:11
verses.text: Besides, it shows the Lord's passion, if you understand it mystically thus: the oil (ἔλαιον) is the Lord Himself, from whom comes the mercy (ἔλεος) which reaches us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:12
verses.text: But the ointment, which is adulterated oil, is the traitor Judas, by whom the Lord was anointed on the feet, being released from His sojourn in the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:13
verses.text: For the dead are anointed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:14
verses.text: And the tears are we repentant sinners, who have believed in Him, and to whom He has forgiven our sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:15
verses.text: And the dishevelled hair is mourning Jerusalem, the deserted, for whom the prophetic lamentations were uttered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:16
verses.text: The Lord Himself shall teach us that Judas the deceitful is meant: "He that dippeth with Me in the dish, the same shall betray Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:17
verses.text: You see the treacherous guest, and this same Judas betrayed the Master with a kiss.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:18
verses.text: For he was a hypocrite, giving a treacherous kiss, in imitation of another hypocrite of old.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:19
verses.text: And He reproves that people respecting whom it was said, "This people honour Me with their lips; but their heart is far from Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:20
verses.text: It is not improbable, therefore, that by the oil He means that disciple to whom was shown mercy, and by the tainted and poisoned oil the traitor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:21
verses.text: This was, then, what the anointed feet prophesied—the treason of Judas, when the Lord went to His passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:22
verses.text: And the Saviour Himself washing the feet of the disciples, and despatching them to do good deeds, pointed out their pilgrimage for the benefit of the nations, making them beforehand fair and pure by His power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:23
verses.text: Then the ointment breathed on them its fragrance, and the work of sweet savour reaching to all was proclaimed; for the passion of the Lord has filled us with sweet fragrance, and the Hebrews with guilt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:24
verses.text: This the apostle most clearly showed, when he said, "thanks be to God, who always makes us to triumph in Christ, and maketh manifest the savour of His knowledge by us in every place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:25
verses.text: For we are to God a sweet savour of the Lord, in them that are saved, and them that are lost; to one a savour of death unto death, to the other a savour of life unto life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:26
verses.text: And the kings of the Jews using gold and precious stones and a variegated crown, the anointed ones wearing Christ symbolically on the head, were unconsciously adorned with the head of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:27
verses.text: The precious stone, or pearl, or emerald, points out the Word Himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:28
verses.text: The gold, again, is the incorruptible Word, who admits not the poison of corruption.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:29
verses.text: The Magi, accordingly, brought to Him on His birth, gold, the symbol of royalty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:30
verses.text: And this crown, after the image of the Lord, fades not as a flower.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:31
verses.text: I know, too, the words of Aristippus the Cyrenian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:32
verses.text: Aristippus was a luxurious man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:33
verses.text: He asked an answer to a sophistical proposition in the following terms: "A horse anointed with ointment is not injured in his excellence as a horse, nor is a dog which has been anointed, in his excellence as a dog; no more is a man," he added, and so finished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:34
verses.text: But the dog and horse take no account of the ointment, whilst in the case of those whose perceptions are more rational, applying girlish scents to their persons, its use is more censurable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:35
verses.text: Of these ointments there are endless varieties, such as the Brenthian, the Metallian, and the royal; the Plangonian and the Psagdian of Egypt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:36
verses.text: Simonides is not ashamed in Iambic lines to say,—  "I was anointed with ointments and perfumes, And with nard".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:37
verses.text: For a merchant was present.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:38
verses.text: They use, too, the unguent made from lilies, and that from the cypress.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:39
verses.text: Nard is in high estimation with them, and the ointment prepared from roses and the others which women use besides, both moist and dry, scents for rubbing and for fumigating; for day by day their thoughts are directed to the gratification of insatiable desire, to the exhaustless variety of fragrance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:40
verses.text: Wherefore also they are redolent of an excessive luxuriousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:41
verses.text: And they fumigate and sprinkle their clothes, their bed-clothes, and their houses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:42
verses.text: Luxury all but compels vessels for the meanest uses to smell of perfume.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:43
verses.text: There are some who, annoyed at the attention bestowed on this, appear to me to be rightly so averse to perfumes on account of their rendering manhood effeminate, as to banish their compounders and vendors from well-regulated states, and banish, too, the dyers of flower-coloured wools.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:44
verses.text: For it is not right that ensnaring garments and unguents should be admitted into the city of truth; but it is highly requisite for the men who belong to us to give forth the odour not of ointments, but of nobleness and goodness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:45
verses.text: And let woman breathe the odour of the true royal ointment, that of Christ, not of unguents and scented powders; and let her always be anointed with the ambrosial chrism of modesty, and find delight in the holy unguent, the Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:46
verses.text: This ointment of pleasant fragrance Christ prepares for His disciples, compounding the ointment of celestial aromatic ingredients.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:47
verses.text: Wherefore also the Lord Himself is anointed with an ointment, as is mentioned by David: "Wherefore God, thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy fellows; myrrh, and stacte, and cassia from thy garments".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:48
verses.text: But let us not unconsciously abominate unguents, like vultures or like beetles (for these, they say, when smeared with ointment, die); and let a few unguents be selected by women, such as will not be overpowering to a husband.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:49
verses.text: For excessive anointings with unguents savour of a funeral and not of connubial life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:50
verses.text: Yet oil itself is inimical to bees and insects; and some men it benefits, and some it summons to the fight; and those who were formerly friends, when anointed with it, it turns out to deadly combat.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:51
verses.text: Ointment being smooth oil, do you not think that it is calculated to render noble manners effeminate? Certainly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:52
verses.text: And as we have abandoned luxury in taste, so certainly do we renounce voluptuousness in sights and odours; lest through the senses, as through unwatched doors, we unconsciously give access into the soul to that excess which we have driven away.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:53
verses.text: If, then, we say that the Lord the great High Priest offers to God the incense of sweet fragrance, let us not imagine that this is a sacrifice and sweet fragrance of incense; but let us understand it to mean, that the Lord lays the acceptable offering of love, the spiritual fragrance, on the altar.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:54
verses.text: To resume: oil itself suffices to lubricate the skin, and relax the nerves, and remove any heavy smell from the body, if we require oil for this purpose.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:55
verses.text: But attention to sweet scents is a bait which draws us in to sensual lust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:56
verses.text: For the licentious man is led on every hand, both by his food, his bed, his conversation, by his eyes, his ears, his jaws, and by his nostrils too.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:57
verses.text: As oxen are pulled by rings and ropes, so is the voluptuary by fumigations and unguents, and the sweet scents of crowns.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:58
verses.text: But since we assign no place to pleasure which is linked to no use serviceable to life, come let us also distinguish here too, selecting what is useful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:59
verses.text: For there are sweet scents which neither make the head heavy nor provoke love, and are not redolent of embraces and licentious companionship, but, along with moderation, are salutary, nourishing the brain when labouring under indisposition, and strengthening the stomach.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:60
verses.text: One must not therefore refrigerate himself with flowers when he wishes to supple his nerves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:61
verses.text: For their use is not wholly to be laid aside, but ointment is to be employed as a medicine and help in order to bring up the strength when enfeebled, and against catarrhs, and colds, and ennui, as the comic poet says:—  "The nostrils are anointed; it being A most essential thing for health to fill the brain with good odours".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:62
verses.text: The rubbing of the feet also with the fatness of warming or cooling unguents is practiced on account of its beneficial effects; so consequently, in the case of those who are thus saturated, an attraction and flow take place from the head to the inferior members.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:63
verses.text: But pleasure to which no utility attaches, induces the suspicion of meretricious habits, and is a drug provocative of the passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:64
verses.text: Rubbing one's self with ointment is entirely different from anointing one's self with ointment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:65
verses.text: The former is effeminate, while anointing with ointment is in some cases beneficial.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:66
verses.text: Aristippus the philosopher, accordingly, when anointed with ointment, said "that the wretched Cinoedi deserved to perish miserably for bringing the utility of ointment into bad repute".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:67
verses.text: "Honour the physician for his usefulness," says the Scripture, "for the Most High made him; and the art of healing is of the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:68
verses.text: Then he adds, "And the compounder of unguents will make the mixture," since unguents have been given manifestly for use, not for voluptuousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:69
verses.text: For we are by no means to care for the exciting properties of unguents, but to choose what is useful in them, since God hath permitted the production of oil for the mitigation of men's pains.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:70
verses.text: And silly women, who dye their grey hair and anoint their locks, grow speedily greyer by the perfumes they use, which are of a drying nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:71
verses.text: Wherefore also those that anoint themselves become drier, and the dryness makes them greyer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:72
verses.text: For if greyness is an exsiccation of the hair, or defect of heat, the dryness drinking up the moisture which is the natural nutriment of the hair, and making it grey, how can we any longer retain a liking for unguents, through which ladies, in trying to escape grey hair, become grey? And as dogs with fine sense of smell track the wild beasts by the scent, so also the temperate scent the licentious by the superfluous perfume of unguents.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:73
verses.text: Such a use of crowns, also, has degenerated to scenes of revelry and intoxication.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:74
verses.text: Do not encircle my head with a crown, for in the springtime it is delightful to while away the time on the dewy meads, while soft and many-coloured flowers are in bloom, and, like the bees, enjoy a natural and pure fragrance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:75
verses.text: But to adorn one's self with "a crown woven from the fresh mead," and wear it at home, were unfit for a man of temperance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:76
verses.text: For it is not suitable to fill the wanton hair with rose-leaves, or violets, or lilies, or other such flowers, stripping the sward of its flowers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:77
verses.text: For a crown encircling the head cools the hair, both on account of its moisture and its coolness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:78
verses.text: Accordingly, physicians, determining by physiology that the brain is cold, approve of anointing the breast and the points of the nostrils, so that the warm exhalation passing gently through, may salutarily warm the chill.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:79
verses.text: A man ought not therefore to cool himself with flowers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:80
verses.text: Besides, those who crown themselves destroy the pleasure there is in flowers: for they enjoy neither the sight of them, since they wear the crown above their eyes; nor their fragrance, since they put the flowers away above the organs of respiration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:81
verses.text: For the fragrance ascending and exhaling naturally, the organ of respiration is left destitute of enjoyment, the fragrance being carried away.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:82
verses.text: As beauty, so also the flower delights when looked at; and it is meet to glorify the Creator by the enjoyment of the sight of beautiful objects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:83
verses.text: The use of them is injurious, and passes swiftly away, avenged by remorse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:84
verses.text: Very soon their evanescence is proved; for both fade, both the flower and beauty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:85
verses.text: Further, whoever touches them is cooled by the former, inflamed by the latter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:86
verses.text: In one word, the enjoyment of them except by sight is a crime, and not luxury.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:87
verses.text: It becomes us who truly follow the Scripture to enjoy ourselves temperately, as in Paradise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:88
verses.text: We must regard the woman's crown to be her husband, and the husband's crown to be marriage; and the flowers of marriage the children of both, which the divine husbandman plucks from meadows of flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:89
verses.text: "Children's children are the crown of old men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:90
verses.text: And the glory of children is their fathers, it is said; and our glory is the Father of all; and the crown of the whole church is Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:91
verses.text: As roots and plants, so also have flowers their individual properties, some beneficial, some injurious, some also dangerous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:92
verses.text: The ivy is cooling; nux emits a stupefying effluvium, as the etymology shows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:93
verses.text: The narcissus is a flower with a heavy odour; the name evinces this, and it induces a torpor (νάρκην) in the nerves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:94
verses.text: And the effluvia of roses and violets being mildly cool, relieve and prevent headaches.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:95
verses.text: But we who are not only not permitted to drink with others to intoxication, but not even to indulge in much wine, do not need the crocus or the flower of the cypress to lead us to an easy sleep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:96
verses.text: Many of them also, by their odours, warm the brain, which is naturally cold, volatilizing the effusions of the head.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:97
verses.text: The rose is hence said to have received its name (ῥόδον) because it emits a copious stream (ῥεῦμα) of odour (ὀδωδή).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:98
verses.text: Wherefore also it quickly fades.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:99
verses.text: But the use of crowns did not exist at all among the ancient Greeks; for neither the suitors nor the luxurious Phaeacians used them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:100
verses.text: But at the games there was at first the gift to the athletes; second, the rising up to applaud; third, the strewing with leaves; lastly, the crown, Greece after the Median war having given herself up to luxury.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:101
verses.text: Those, then, who are trained by the Word are restrained from the use of crowns; and do not think that this Word, which has its seat in the brain, ought to be bound about, not because the crown is the symbol of the recklessness of revelry, but because it has been dedicated to idols.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:102
verses.text: Sophocles accordingly called the narcissus "the ancient coronet of the great gods," speaking of the earth-born divinities; and Sappho crowns the Muses with the rose:—  "For thou dost not share in roses from Pieria".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:103
verses.text: They say, too, that Here delights in the lily, and Artemis in the myrtle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:104
verses.text: For if the flowers were made especially for man, and senseless people have taken them not for their own proper and grateful use, but have abused them to the thankless service of demons, we must keep from them for conscience sake.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:105
verses.text: The crown is the symbol of untroubled tranquillity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:106
verses.text: For this reason they crown the dead, and idols, too, on the same account, by this fact giving testimony to their being dead.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:107
verses.text: For revellers do not without crowns celebrate their orgies; and when once they are encircled with flowers, at last they are inflamed excessively.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:108
verses.text: We must have no communion with demons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:109
verses.text: Nor must we crown the living image of God after the manner of dead idols.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:110
verses.text: For the fair crown of amaranth is laid up for those who have lived well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:111
verses.text: This flower the earth is not able to bear; heaven alone is competent to produce it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:112
verses.text: Further, it were irrational in us, who have heard that the Lord was crowned with thorns, to crown ourselves with flowers, insulting thus the sacred passion of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:113
verses.text: For the Lord's crown prophetically pointed to us, who once were barren, but are placed around Him through the Church of which He is the Head.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:114
verses.text: But it is also a type of faith, of life in respect of the substance of the wood, of joy in respect of the appellation of crown, of danger in respect of the thorn, for there is no approaching to the Word without blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:115
verses.text: But this platted crown fades, and the plait of perversity is untied, and the flower withers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:116
verses.text: For the glory of those who have not believed on the Lord fades.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:117
verses.text: And they crowned Jesus raised aloft, testifying to their own ignorance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:118
verses.text: For being hard of heart, they understood not that this very thing, which they called the disgrace of the Lord, was a prophecy wisely uttered: "The Lord was not known by the people" which erred, which was not circumcised in understanding, whose darkness was not enlightened, which knew not God, denied the Lord, forfeited the place of the true Israel, persecuted God, hoped to reduce the Word to disgrace; and Him whom they crucified as a malefactor they crowned as a king.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:119
verses.text: Wherefore the Man on whom they believed not, they shall know to be the loving God the Lord, the Just.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:120
verses.text: Whom they provoked to show Himself to be the Lord, to Him when lifted up they bore witness, by encircling Him, who is exalted above every name, with the diadem of righteousness by the ever-blooming thorn.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:121
verses.text: This diadem, being hostile to those who plot against Him, coerces them; and friendly to those who form the Church, defends them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:122
verses.text: This crown is the flower of those who have believed on the glorified One, but covers with blood and chastises those who have not believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:123
verses.text: It is a symbol, too, of the Lord's successful work, He having borne on His head, the princely part of His body, all our iniquities by which we were pierced.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:124
verses.text: For He by His own passion rescued us from offences, and sins, and such like thorns; and having destroyed the devil, deservedly said in triumph, "O Death, where is thy sting?" And we eat grapes from thorns, and figs from thistles; while those to whom He stretched forth His hands—the disobedient and unfruitful people—He lacerates into wounds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:125
verses.text: I can also show you another mystic meaning in it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:126
verses.text: For when the Almighty Lord of the universe began to legislate by the Word, and wished His power to be manifested to Moses, a godlike vision of light that had assumed a shape was shown him in the burning bush (the bush is a thorny plant); but when the Word ended the giving of the law and His stay with men, the Lord was again mystically crowned with thorn.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:127
verses.text: On His departure from this world to the place whence He came, He repeated the beginning of His old descent, in order that the Word beheld at first in the bush, and afterwards taken up crowned by the thorn, might show the whole to be the work of one power, He Himself being one, the Son of the Father, who is truly one, the beginning and the end of time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:128
verses.text: But I have made a digression from the paedagogic style of speech, and introduced the didactic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:129
verses.text: I return accordingly to my subject.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:130
verses.text: To resume, then: we have showed that in the department of medicine, for healing, and sometimes also for moderate recreation, the delight derived from flowers, and the benefit derived from unguents and perfumes, are not to be overlooked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:131
verses.text: And if some say, What pleasure, then, is there in flowers to those that do not use them? let them know, then, that unguents are prepared from them, and are most useful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:132
verses.text: The Susinian ointment is made from various kinds of lilies; and it is warming, aperient, drawing, moistening, abstergent, subtle, antibilious, emollient.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:133
verses.text: The Narcissinian is made from the narcissus, and is equally beneficial with the Susinian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:134
verses.text: The Myrsinian, made of myrtle and myrtle berries, is a styptic, stopping effusions from the body; and that from roses is refrigerating.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:135
verses.text: For, in a word, these also were created for our use.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:136
verses.text: "Hear me," it is said, "and grow as a rose planted by the streams of waters, and give forth a sweet fragrance like frankincense, and bless the Lord for His works".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:137
verses.text: We should have much to say respecting them, were we to speak of flowers and odours as made for necessary purposes, and not for the excesses of luxury.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:138
verses.text: And if a concession must be made, it is enough for people to enjoy the fragrance of flowers; but let them not crown themselves with them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:139
verses.text: For the Father takes great care of man, and gives to him alone His own art.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 9:140
verses.text: The Scripture therefore says, "Water, and fire, and iron, and milk, and fine flour of wheat, and honey, the blood of the grape, and oil, and clothing,—all these things are for the good of the godly".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:1
verses.text: Chapter - 9—On Sleep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:2
verses.text: How, in due course, we are to go to sleep, in remembrance of the precepts of temperance, we must now say.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:3
verses.text: For after the repast, having given thanks to God for our participation in our enjoyments, and for the happy passing of the day, our talk must be turned to sleep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:4
verses.text: Magnificence of bed-clothes, gold-embroidered carpets, and smooth carpets worked with gold, and long fine robes of purple, and costly fleecy cloaks, and manufactured rugs of purple, and mantles of thick pile, and couches softer than sleep, are to be banished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:5
verses.text: For, besides the reproach of voluptuousness, sleeping on downy feathers is injurious, when our bodies fall down as into a yawning hollow, on account of the softness of the bedding.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:6
verses.text: For they are not convenient for sleepers turning in them, on account of the bed rising into a hill on either side of the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:7
verses.text: Nor are they suitable for the digestion of the food, but rather for burning it up, and so destroying the nutriment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:8
verses.text: But stretching one's self on even couches, affording a kind of natural gymnasium for sleep, contributes to the digestion of the food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:9
verses.text: And those that can roll on other beds, having this, as it were, for a natural gymnasium for sleep, digest food more easily, and render themselves fitter for emergencies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:10
verses.text: Moreover, silver-footed couches argue great ostentation; and the ivory on beds, the body having left the soul, is not permissible for holy men, being a lazy contrivance for rest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:11
verses.text: We must not occupy our thoughts about these things, for the use of them is not forbidden to those who possess them; but solicitude about them is prohibited, for happiness is not to be found in them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:12
verses.text: On the other hand, it savours of cynic vanity for a man to act as Diomede,—  "And he stretched himself under a wild bull's hide,"— unless circumstances compel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:13
verses.text: Ulysses rectified the unevenness of the nuptial couch with a stone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:14
