verses.text: Such frugality and self-help was practiced not by private individuals alone, but by the chiefs of the ancient Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:15
verses.text: But why speak of these? Jacob slept on the ground, and a stone served him for a pillow; and then was he counted worthy to behold the vision—that was above man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:16
verses.text: And in conformity with reason, the bed which we use must be simple and frugal, and so constructed that, by avoiding the extremes of too much indulgence and too much endurance, it may be comfortable: if it is warm, to protect us; if cold, to warm us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:17
verses.text: But let not the couch be elaborate, and let it have smooth feet; for elaborate turnings form occasionally paths for creeping things which twine themselves about the incisions of the work, and do not slip off.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:18
verses.text: Especially is a moderate softness in the bed suitable for manhood; for sleep ought not to be for the total enervation of the body, but for its relaxation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:19
verses.text: Wherefore I say that it ought not to be allowed to come on us for the sake of indulgence, but in order to rest from action.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:20
verses.text: We must therefore sleep so as to be easily awaked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:21
verses.text: For it is said, "Let your loins be girt about, and your lamps burning; and ye yourselves like to men that watch for their lord, that when he returns from the marriage, and comes and knocks, they may straightway open to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:22
verses.text: Blessed are those servants whom the Lord, when He cometh, shall find watching".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:23
verses.text: For there is no use of a sleeping man, as there is not of a dead man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:24
verses.text: Wherefore we ought often to rise by night and bless God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:25
verses.text: For blessed are they who watch for Him, and so make themselves like the angels, whom we call "watchers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:26
verses.text: But a man asleep is worth nothing, any more than if he were not alive.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:27
verses.text: But he who has the light watches, "and darkness seizes not on him," nor sleep, since darkness does not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:28
verses.text: He that is illuminated is therefore awake towards God; and such an one lives.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:29
verses.text: "For what was made in Him was life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:30
verses.text: "Blessed is the man," says Wisdom, "who shall hear me, and the man who shall keep my ways, watching at my doors, daily observing the posts of my entrances".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:31
verses.text: "Let us not then sleep, as do others, but let us watch," says the Scripture, "and be sober.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:32
verses.text: For they that sleep, sleep in the night; and they that be drunken, are drunken in the night," that is, in the darkness of ignorance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:33
verses.text: "But let us who are of the day be sober.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:34
verses.text: For ye are all children of the light, and children of the day; we are not of the night, nor of the darkness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:35
verses.text: But whoever of us is most solicitous for living the true life, and for entertaining noble sentiments, will keep awake for as long time as possible, reserving to himself only what in this respect is conducive to his own health; and that is not very usual.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:36
verses.text: But devotion to activity begets an everlasting vigil after toils.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:37
verses.text: Let not food weigh us down, but lighten us; that we may be injured as little as possible by sleep, as those that swim with weights hanging to them are weighed down.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:38
verses.text: But, on the other hand, let temperance raise us as from the abyss beneath to the enterprises of wakefulness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:39
verses.text: For the oppression of sleep is like death, which forces us into insensibility, cutting off the light by the closing of the eyelids.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:40
verses.text: Let not us, then, who are sons of the true light, close the door against this light; but turning in on ourselves, illumining the eyes of the hidden man, and gazing on the truth itself, and receiving its streams, let us clearly and intelligibly reveal such dreams as are true.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:41
verses.text: But the hiccuping of those who are loaded with wine, and the snortings of those who are stuffed with food, and the snoring rolled in the bed-clothes, and the rumblings of pained stomachs, cover over the clear-seeing eye of the soul, by filling the mind with ten thousand phantasies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:42
verses.text: And the cause is too much food, which drags the rational part of man down to a condition of stupidity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:43
verses.text: For much sleep brings advantage neither to our bodies nor our souls; nor is it suitable at all to those processes which have truth for their object, although agreeable to nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:44
verses.text: Now, just Lot (for I pass over at present the account of the economy of regeneration) would not have been drawn into that unhallowed intercourse, had he not been intoxicated by his daughters, and overpowered by sleep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:45
verses.text: If, therefore, we cut off the causes of great tendency to sleep, we shall sleep the more soberly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:46
verses.text: For those who have the sleepless Word dwelling in them, ought not to sleep the livelong night; but they ought to rise by night, especially when the days are coming to an end, and one devote himself to literature, another begin his art, the women handle the distaff, and all of us should, so to speak, fight against sleep, accustoming ourselves to this gently and gradually, so that through wakefulness we may partake of life for a longer period.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:47
verses.text: We, then, who assign the best part of the night to wakefulness, must by no manner of means sleep by day; and fits of uselessness, and napping and stretching one's self, and yawning, are manifestations of frivolous uneasiness of soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:48
verses.text: And in addition to all, we must know this, that the need of sleep is not in the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:49
verses.text: For it is ceaselessly active.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:50
verses.text: But the body is relieved by being resigned to rest, the soul whilst not acting through the body, but exercising intelligence within itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:51
verses.text: Thus also, such dreams as are true, in the view of him who reflects rightly, are the thoughts of a sober soul, undistracted for the time by the affections of the body, and counselling with itself in the best manner.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:52
verses.text: For the soul to cease from activity within itself, were destruction to it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 10:53
verses.text: Wherefore always contemplating God, and by perpetual converse with Him inoculating the body with wakefulness, it raises man to equality with angelic grace, and from the practice of wakefulness it grasps the eternity of life.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—Quaenam de Procreatione Liberorum Tractanda Sint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:2
verses.text: Tempus autem opportunum conjunctionis solis iis relinquitur considerandum, qui juncti sunt matrimonio; qui autem matrimonio juncti sunt, iis scopus est et institutum, liberorum susceptio: finis autem, ut boni sint liberi: quemadmodum agricolae seminis quidem dejectionis causa est, quod nutrimenti habendi curam gerat; agriculturae autem finis est, fructuum perceptio.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:3
verses.text: Multo autem melior est agricola, qui terram colit animatam: ille enim ed tempus alimentum expetens, hic vero ut universum permanent, curam gerens, agricolaeofficio fungitur: et ille quidem propter se, hic vero propter Deum plantat ac seminat.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:4
verses.text: Dixit enim: "Multiplicemini;" ubi hoc subaudiendum est: "Et ea ratione fit homo Dei imago, quatenus homo co-operatur ad generationem hominis".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:5
verses.text: Non est quaelibet terra apta ad suscipienda semina: quod si etiam sit quaelibet, non tamen eidem agricolae.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:6
verses.text: Neque vero seminandum est supra petram, neque semen est contumlia afficiendum, quod quidem dux est et princeps generationis, estque substantia, quae simul habet insitas naturae rationes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:7
verses.text: Quae sunt autem secundum naturam rationes, absque ratione praeternaturalibus mandando meatibus, ignominia afficere, valde est impium.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:8
verses.text: Videte itaque quomodo sapientissimus Moyses infrugiferam aliquando sationem symbolice repulerit: "Non comedes, inquiens, leporem, nec hyaenam".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:9
verses.text: Non vult homines esse qualitatis eorum participes, neque eis aequalem gustare libidinem: haec enim animalia ad explendum coitum venereum feruntur insano quodam furore.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:10
verses.text: Ac leporem quidem dicunt quotannis multiplicare anum, pro numero annorum, quos vixit, habentem foramina: et ea ratione dum leporis esum prohibet, significat se dehortari puerorum amorem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:11
verses.text: Hyaenam autem vicissim singulis annis masculinum sexum mutare in femininum: significare autem non esse illi ad adulteria prorumpendum, qui ab hyaena abstinet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:12
verses.text: Well, I also agree that the consummately wise Moses confessedly indicates by the prohibition before us, that we must not resemble these animals; but I do not assent to the explanation of what has been symbolically spoken.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:13
verses.text: For nature never can be forced to change.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:14
verses.text: What once has been impressed on it, may not be transformed into the opposite by passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:15
verses.text: For passion is not nature, and passion is wont to deface the form, not to cast it into a new shape.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:16
verses.text: Though many birds are said to change with the seasons, both in colour and voice, as the blackbird (κόσσυφος), which becomes yellow from black, and a chatterer from a singing-bird.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:17
verses.text: Similarly also the nightingale changes by turns both its colour and note.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:18
verses.text: But they do not alter their nature itself, so as in the transformation to become female from male.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:19
verses.text: But the new crop of feathers, like new clothes, produces a kind of colouring of the feathers, and a little after it evaporates in the rigour of winter, as a flower when its colour fades.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:20
verses.text: And in like manner the voice itself, injured by the cold, is enfeebled.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:21
verses.text: For, in consequence of the outer skin being thickened by the surrounding air, the arteries about the neck being compressed and filled, press hard on the breath; which being very much confined, emits a stifled sound.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:22
verses.text: When, again, the breath is assimilated to the surrounding air and relaxed in spring, it is freed from its confined condition, and is carried through the dilated, though till then obstructed arteries, it warbles no longer a dying melody, but now gives forth a shrill note; and the voice flows wide, and spring now becomes the song of the voice of birds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:23
verses.text: Nequaquam ergo credendum est, hyaenam unquam mutare naturam: idem enim animal non habet simul ambo pudenda maris et feminae, sicut nonnulli existimarunt, qui prodigiose hermaphroditos finxerunt, et inter marem et feminam, hanc masculo-feminam naturam innovarunt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:24
verses.text: Valde autem falluntur, ut qui non animadverterint, quam sit filiorum amans omnium mater et genetrix Natura: quoniam enim hoc animal, hyaena inquam, est salacissimum, sub cauda ante excrementi meatum, adnatum est ei quoddam carneum tuberculum, feminino pudendo figura persimile.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:25
verses.text: Nullum autem meatum habet haec figura carnis, qui in utilem aliquam desinat partem, vel in matricem inquam, vel in rectum intestinum: tantum habet magnam concavitatem, quae inanem excipiat libidinem, quando aversi fuerint meatus, qui in concipiendo fetu occupati sunt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:26
verses.text: Hoc ipsum autem et masculo et feminae hyaenae adnatum est, quod sit insigniter pathica: masculus enim vicissim et agit, et patitur: unde etiam rarissime inveniri potest hyaena femina: non enim frequenter concipit hoc animal, cum in eis largiter redundet ea, quae praeter naturam est, satio.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:27
verses.text: Hac etiam ratione mihi videtur Plato in Phoedro, amorem puerorum repellens, eum appellate bestiam, quod frenum mordentes, qui se voluptatibus dedunt, libidinosi, quadrupedum coeunt more, et filios seminare conantur.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:28
verses.text: Impios "autem tradidit Deus," ut air Apostolus, "in perturbationes ignominiae: nam et feminaeeorum mutaverunt naturalem usum in eum, qui est procter naturam: similiter autem et masculi eorum, relicto usu naturali, exarserunt in desiderio sui inter se invicem, masculi in masculos turpitudinem operantes, et mercedem, quam oportuit, erroris sui in se recipientes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:29
verses.text: At vero ne libidinosissimis quidem animantibus concessit natura in excrementi meatum semen immittere: urina enim in vesicam excernitur, humefactum alimentum in ventrum, lacryma vero in oculum, sanguis in venas, sordes in aures, mucus in hares defertur: fini autem recti intestini, sedes cohaeret, per quam excrementa exponuntur.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:30
verses.text: Sola ergo varia in hyaenis natura, superfluo coitui superfluam hanc partem excogitavit, et ideo est etiam aliquantisper concavum, ut prurientibus partibus inserviat, exinde autem excaecatur concavitas: non fuit emm res fabricata ad generationem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:31
verses.text: Hinc nobis manifestum atque adeo in confesso est, vitandos esse cum masculis concubitus, et infrugiferas sationes, et Venerem praeposteram, et quae natura coalescere non possunt, androgynorum conjunctiones, ipsam naturam sequentibus, quae id per partium prohibet constitutionem, ut quae masculum non ad semen suscipiendum, sed ad id effundendum fecerit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:32
verses.text: Jeremias autem, hoc est, per ipsum loquens Spiritus, quando dicit: "Spelunca hyaenae facta est domus mea," id quod ex mortuis constabat corporibus detestans alimentum, sapienti allegoria reprehendit cultum simulacrorum: vere enim oportet ab idolis esse puram domum Dei viventis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:33
verses.text: Rursus Moyses lepore quoque vesci prohibet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:34
verses.text: Omni enim tempore coit lepus, et salit, assidente femina, earn a tergo aggrediens: est enim ex iis, quae retro insiliunt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:35
verses.text: Concipit autem singulis mensibus, et superfetat; init autem, et parit; postquam autem peperit, statim a quovis initur lepore (neque enim uno contenta est matrimonio) et rursus concipit, adhuc lactans: habet enim matricem, cui sunt duo sinus, et non unus solus matricis vacuus sinus, est ei sufficiens sedes ad receptaculure coitus (quidquid enim est vacuum, desiderat repleri); verum accidit, ut cure uterum gerunt, altera pars matricis desiderio teneatur et libidine furiat; quocirca fiunt eis superfetationes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:36
verses.text: A vehementibus ergo appetitionibus, mutuisque congressionibus, et cure praegnantibus feminis conjunctionibus, alternisque initibus, puerorumque stupris, adulteriis et libidine abstinere, hujus nos aenigmatis adhortata est prohibitio.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:37
verses.text: Idcirco aperte, et non per renigmata Moyses prohibuit, "Non fornicaberis; non moechaberis; pueris stuprum non inferes," inquiens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:38
verses.text: Logi itaque praescriptum totis viribus observandum, neque quidquam contra leges ullo modo faciendum est, neque mandata sunt infirmanda.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:39
verses.text: Malaeenim.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:40
verses.text: cupiditati nomen est ὕβρις, "petulantia;" et equum cupiditatis, "petulantem" vocavit Plato, cure legissit, "Facti estis mihi equi furentes in feminas".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:41
verses.text: Libidines autem supplicium notum nobis facient illi, qui Sodomam accesserunt, angeli.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:42
verses.text: Li eos, qui probro illos afficere voluerunt, una cum ipsa civitate combusserunt, evidenti hoc indicio ignem, qui est fructus libidinis, describentes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:43
verses.text: Quaeenim veteribus acciderunt, sicut ante diximus, ad nos admonendos scripta sunt, ne eisdem teneamur vitiis, et caveamus, ne in poenas similes incidamus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:44
verses.text: Oportet autem filios existimare, pueros; uxores autem alienas intueri tanquam proprias filias: voluptates quippe continere, ventrique et iis quae sunt infra ventrem, dominari, est maximi imperii.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:45
verses.text: Si enim ne digitum quidem temere movere permittit sapienti ratio, ut confitentur Stoici, quomodo non multo magis iis, qui sapientiam persequuntur, in eam, qua coitur, particulam dominatus est obtinendus? Atque hac quidem de causa videtur esse nominatum pudendum, quod hac corporis parte magis, quam qualibet alia, cum pudore utendum sit; natura enim sicut alimentis, ita etiam legitimis nuptiis, quantum convenit, utile est, et decet, nobis uti permisit: permisit autem appetere liberorum procreationem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:46
verses.text: Quicumque autem, quod modum excedit, persequuntur, labuntur in eo quod est secundum naturam, per congressus, qui sunt praeter leges, seipsos laedentes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:47
verses.text: Ante omnia enim recte habet, ut nunquam cure adolescentibus perinde ac cum feminis, Veneris utamur consuetudine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:48
verses.text: Et ideo "non esse in petris et lapidibus seminandum" dicit, qui a Moyse factus est philosophus, "quoniam nunquam actis radicibus genitalem sit semen naturam suscepturum".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:49
verses.text: Logos itaque per Moysen appertissime praecepit: "Et cure masculo non dormies feminino concubitu: est enim abominatio".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:50
verses.text: Accedit his, quod "ab omni quoque arvo feminino esse abstinendum" praeterquam a proprio, ex divinis Scripturis colligens praeclarus Plato consuluit lege illinc accepta: "Et uxori proximi tui non dabis concubitum seminis, ut polluaris apud ipsam.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:51
verses.text: Irrita autem sunt et adulterina concubinarum semina.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:52
verses.text: Ne semina, ubi non vis tibi nasci quod seminatum est.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:53
verses.text: Neque ullam omnino tange mulierem, praeterquam tuam ipsius uxorem," ex qua sola tibi licet carnis voluptates percipere ad suscipiendam legitimam successionem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:54
verses.text: Haec enim Logo sola sunt legitima.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:55
verses.text: Eis quidem certe, qui divini muneris in producendo opificio sunt participes, semen non est abjiciendum, neque injuria afficiendum, neque tanquam si cornibus semen mandes seminandum est.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:56
verses.text: Hic ipse ergo Moyses cum ipsis quoque prohibet uxoribus congredi, si forte eas detineant purgationes menstruae.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:57
verses.text: Non enim purgamento corporis genitale semen, et quod mox homo futurum est, polluere est aequum, nec sordido materiae profluvio, et, quae expurgantur, inquinamentis inundare ac obruere; semen autem generationis degenerat, ineptumque redditur, simatricis sulcis privetur.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:58
verses.text: Neque vero ullum unquam induxit veterum Hebraeorum coeuntem cum sua uxore praegnante.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:59
verses.text: Sola enim voluptas, si quis ea etiam utatur in conjugio, est praeter leges, et injusta, eta ratione aliena.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:60
verses.text: Rursus autem Moyses abducit viros a praegnantibus, quousque pepererint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:61
verses.text: Revera enim matrix sub vesica quidem collocata, super intestinum autem, quod rectum appellatur, posita, extendit collum inter humeros in vesica; et os colli, in quod venit semen, impletum occluditur, illa autem rursus inanis redditur, cum partu purgata fuerit: fructu autem deposito, deinde semen suscipit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:62
verses.text: Neque vero nobis turpe est ad auditorum utilitatem nominare partes, in quibus fit fetus conceptio, quae quidem Deum fabricari non puduit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:63
verses.text: Matrix itaque sitiens filiorum procreationem, semen suscipit, probrosumque et vituperandum negat coitum, post sationem ore clauso omnino jam libidinem excludens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:64
verses.text: Ejus autem appetitiones, quae prius in amicis versabantur complexibus, intro conversae, in procreatione sobolis occupatae, operantur una cum Opifice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:65
verses.text: Nefas est ergo operantem jam naturam adhuc molestia afficere, superflue ad petulantem prorumpendo libidinem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:66
verses.text: Petulantia autem, quae multa quidem habet nomina, et multas species, cure ad hanc veneream intemperantiam deflexerit, λαγνεία, id est "lascivia," dicitur; quo nomine significatur libidinosa, publica, et incesta in coitum propensio: quae cum aucta fuerit, magna simul morborum convenit multitudo, obsoniorum desiderium, vinolentia et amor in mulieres; luxus quoque, et simul universarum voluptatum studium; in quae omnia tyrannidem obtinet cupidity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:67
verses.text: His autem cognatae innumerabiles augentur affectiones, ex quibus mores intemperantes ad summum provehuntur.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:68
verses.text: Dicit autem Scriptura: "Parantur intemperantibus flagella, et supplicia humeris insipientium:" vires intemperantiae, ejusque constantem tolerantiam, vocans "humeros insipientium".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:69
verses.text: Quocirca, "Amove a servis tuis spes inanes, et indecoras," inquit, "cupiditates averte a me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:70
verses.text: Ventris appetitio et coitus ne me apprehendant".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:71
verses.text: Longe ergo sunt arcenda multifaria insidiatorum maleficia; non ad solam enim Cratetis Peram, sed etiam ad nostram civitatem non navigat stultus parasitus, nec scortator libidinosus, qui posteriori delectatur parte: non dolosa meretrix, nec ulla ejusmodi alia voluptatis bellua.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:72
verses.text: Multa ergo nobis per totam vitam seminetur, quae bona sit et honesta, occupatio.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:73
verses.text: In summa ergo, vel jungi matrimonio, vel omnino a matrimonio purum esse oportet; in quae stione enim id versatur, et hoc nobis declaratum est in libro De continentia.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:74
verses.text: Quod si hoc ipsum, an ducenda sit uxor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:75
verses.text: veniat in considerationem: quomodo libere permittetur, quemadmodum nutrimento, ita etiam coitu semper uti, tanquam re necessaria? Ex eo ergo videri possunt nervi tanquam stamina distrahi, et in vehementi congressus intensione disrumpi.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:76
verses.text: Jam vero offundit etiam caliginem sensibus, et vires enervat.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:77
verses.text: Patet hoc et in animantibus rationis expertibus, et in iis, quae in exercitatione versantur, corporibus; quorum hi quidem, qui abstinent, in certaminibus superant adversarios; illa vero a coitu abducta circumaguntur, et tantum non trahuntur, omnibus viribus et omni impetu tandem quasi enervata.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:78
verses.text: "Parvam epilepsiam" dicebat "coitum" sophista Abderites morbum immedicabilem existimans.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:79
verses.text: Annon enim consequuntur resolutiones, quae exinanitionis ejusque, quod abscedit, magnitudini ascribuntur? "homo enim ex homine nascitur et evellitur".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:80
verses.text: Vide damni magnitudinem: totus homo per exinanitionem coitus abstrahitur.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:81
verses.text: Dicit enim: Hoc nunc os ex ossibus meis, et caro ex came mea".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:82
verses.text: Homo ergo tantum exinanitur semine, quantus videtur corpore; est enim generationis initium id, quod recedit: quin etiam conturbat ebullitio materiae et compagem corporis labefactat et commovet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:83
verses.text: Lepide ergo ille, qui interroganti, "Quomodo adhuc se haberet ad res venereas," respondit: "Bona verba, quae so: ego vero lubentissime isthinc, tanquam ab agresti et insano domino, profugi".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:84
verses.text: Verum concedatur quidem et admittatur matrimonium: vult enim Dominus humanum genus repleri; seal non dicit, Estote libidinosi: nec vos, tanquam ad coitum natos, voluit esse deditos voluptati.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:85
verses.text: Pudore autem nos afficiat Paedagogus, clamans per Ezechielem: "Circumcidamini fornicationem vestram".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:86
verses.text: Aliquod tempus ad seminandum opportunum habent quoque rationis expertia animantia.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:87
verses.text: Aliter autem coire, quam ad liberorum procreationem, est facere injuriam naturae; qua quidem oportetmagistra, quas prudenter introducit temporis commoditates, diligenter observare, senectutem, inquam, et puerilem aetatem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:88
verses.text: His enim nondum concessit, illos autem non vult amplius uxores ducere.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:89
verses.text: Seal non vult homines semper dare operam matrimonio.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:90
verses.text: Matrimonium autem est filiorum procreationis appetitio, non inordinata seminis excretio, quae est et praeter leges eta ratione aliena.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:91
verses.text: Secundum naturam autem nobis vita universa processerit, si et ab initio cupiditates contineamus, et hominum genus, quod ex divina providentia nascitur, improbis et malitiosis non tollamus artibus: eaeenim, ut fornicatiohem celent, exitialia medicamenta adhibentes, quae prorsus in perniciem ducunt, simul cum fetu omnem humanitatem perdunt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:92
verses.text: Caeterum, quibus uxores ducere concessum est, iis Paedagogo opus fuerit, ut non interdiu mystica naturae celebrentur orgia, nec ut aliquis ex ecclesia, verbi gratia, aut ex foro mane rediens, galli more coeat, quando orationis, et lectionis, et eorum quae interdiu facere convenit, operum tempus est.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:93
verses.text: Vespere autem oportet post convivium quiescere, et post gratiarum actionem, quae fit Deo pro bonis quae percepimus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:94
verses.text: Non semper autem concedit tempus natura, ut peragatur congressus matrimonii; est enim eo desiderabilior conjunctio, quo diuturnior.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:95
verses.text: Neque vero noctu, tanquam in tenebris, immodeste sese ac imtemperanter gerere oportet, sed verecundia, ut quae sit lux rationis, in animo est includenda.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:96
verses.text: Nihil enim a Penelope telam texente differemus, si interdiu quidem texamus dogmata temperantiae; noctu autem ea resolvamus, cum in cubile venerimus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:97
verses.text: Si enim honestatem exercere oportet, multo magis tuae uxori honestas est ostendenda, inhonestas vitando conjunctiones: et quod caste cum proximis verseris, fide dignum e domo adsit testimonium.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:98
verses.text: Non enim potest aliquid honestum ab ea existimari, apud quam honestas in acribus illis non probatur certo quasi testimonio voluptatibus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:99
verses.text: Benevolentia autem quae praeceps fertur ad congressionem, exiguo tempore floret, et cum corpore consenescit; nonnunquam autem etiam prae senescit, flaccescente jam libidine, quando matrimonialem temperantiam meretriciae vitiaverint libidines.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:100
verses.text: Amantium enim corda sunt volucria, amorisque irritamenta exstinguuntur saepe poenitentia; amorque saepe vertitur in odium, quando reprehensionera senserit satietas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:101
verses.text: Impudicorum vero verborum, et turpium figurarum, meretriciorumque osculomm, et hujusmodi lasciviarum nomina ne sunt quidem memoranda, beatum sequentibus Apostolum, qui aperte dicit: "Fornicatio autem et omnis immunditia, vel plura habendi cupiditas, ne nominetur quidem in vobis, sicut decet saneros".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:102
verses.text: Recte ergo videtur dixisse quispiam: "Nulli quidem profuit coitus, recte autem cum eo agitur, quem non laeserit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:103
verses.text: Nam et qui legitimus, est periculosus, nisi quatenus in liberorum procreatione versatur.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:104
verses.text: De eo autem, qui est praeter leges, dicit Scriptura: "Mulier meretrix apro similis reputabitur.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:105
verses.text: Quaeautem viro subjecta est, turris est mortis iis, qui ea utuntur".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:106
verses.text: Capro, vel apro, meretricis comparavit affectionem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:107
verses.text: "Mortem" autem dixit "quae sitam," adulterium, quod committitur in meretrice, quae custoditur.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:108
verses.text: "Domum" autem, et "urbem," in qua suam exercent intemperantiam.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:109
verses.text: Quin etiam quae est apud vos poetica, quodammodo ea exprobrans, scribit:—  Tecum et adulterium est, tecum coitusque nefandus, Foedus, femineusque, urbs pessima, plane impura.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:110
verses.text: Econtra autem pudicos admiratur:—  Quos desiderium tenuit nec turpe cubilis Alterius, nec tetra invisaque stupra tulerunt Ulla unquam maribus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:111
verses.text: For many think such things to be pleasures only which are against nature, such as these sins of theirs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:112
verses.text: And those who are better than they, know them to be sins, but are overcome by pleasures, and darkness is the veil of their vicious practices.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:113
verses.text: For he violates his marriage adulterously who uses it in a meretricious way, and hears not the voice of the Instructor, crying, "The man who ascends his bed, who says in his soul, Who seeth me? darkness is around me, and the walls are my covering, and no one sees my sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:114
verses.text: Why do I fear lest the Highest will remember?" Most wretched is such a  man, dreading men's eyes alone, and thinking that he will escape the observation of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:115
verses.text: "For he knoweth not," says the Scripture, "that brighter ten thousand times than the sun are the eyes of the Most High, which look on all the ways of men, and cast their glance into hidden parts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:116
verses.text: Thus again the Instructor threatens them, speaking by Isaiah: "Woe be to those who take counsel in secret, and say, Who seeth us?" For one may escape the light of sense, but that of the mind it is impossible to escape.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:117
verses.text: For how, says Heraclitus, can one escape the notice of that which never sets? Let us by no means, then, veil our selves with the darkness; for the light dwells in us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:118
verses.text: "For the darkness," it is said, "comprehendeth it not".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:119
verses.text: And the very night itself is illuminated by temperate reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:120
verses.text: The thoughts of good men Scripture has named "sleepless lamps;" although for one to attempt even to practice concealment, with reference to what he does, is confessedly to sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:121
verses.text: And every one who sins, directly wrongs not so much his neighbour if he commits adultery, as himself, because he has committed adultery, besides making himself worse and less thought of.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:122
verses.text: For he who sins, in the degree in which he sins, becomes worse and is of less estimation than before; and he who has been overcome by base pleasures, has now licentiousness wholly attached to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:123
verses.text: Wherefore he who commits fornication is wholly dead to God, and is abandoned by the Word as a dead body by the spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:124
verses.text: For what is holy, as is right, abhors to be polluted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:125
verses.text: But it is always lawful for the pure to touch the pure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:126
verses.text: Do not, I pray, put off modesty at the same time that you put off your clothes; because it is never right for the just man to divest himself of continence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:127
verses.text: For, lo, this mortal shall put on immortality; when the insatiableness of desire, which rushes into licentiousness, being trained to self-restraint, and made free from the love of corruption, shall consign the man to everlasting chastity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:128
verses.text: "For in this world they marry and and are given in marriage".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:129
verses.text: But having done with the works of the flesh, and having been clothed with immortality, the flesh itself being pure, we pursue after that which is according to the measure of the angels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:130
verses.text: Thus in the Philebus, Plato, who had been the disciple of the barbarian philosophy, mystically called those Atheists who destroy and pollute, as far as in them lies, the Deity dwelling in them—that is, the Logos—by association with their vices.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:131
verses.text: Those, therefore, who are consecrated to God must never live mortally (θνητῶς).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:132
verses.text: "Nor," as Paul says, "is it meet to make the members of Christ the members of an harlot; nor must the temple of God be made the temple of base affections".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:133
verses.text: Remember the four and twenty thousand that were rejected for fornication.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:134
verses.text: But the experiences of those who have committed fornication, as I have already said, are types which correct our lusts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:135
verses.text: Moreover, the Paedagogue warns us most distinctly: "Go not after thy lusts, and abstain from thine appetites; for wine and women will remove the wise; and he that cleaves to harlots will become more daring.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:136
verses.text: Corruption and the worm shall inherit him, and he shall be held up as public example to greater shame".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:137
verses.text: And again—for he wearies not of doing good—"He who averts his eyes from pleasure crowns his life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:138
verses.text: Non est ergo justum vinci a rebus venereis, nec libidinibus stolide inhiare, nec a ratione alienis appetitionibus moveri, nec desiderare pollui.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:139
verses.text: Ei autem soli, qui uxorem duxit, ut qui tunc sit agricola, serere permissum est; quando tempus sementem admittit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:140
verses.text: Adversus aliam autem intemperantiam, optimum quidem est medicamentum, ratio.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 11:141
verses.text: Fert etiam auxilium penuria satietatis, per quam accensae libidines prosiliunt ad voluptates.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—On Clothes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:2
verses.text: Wherefore neither are we to provide for ourselves costly clothing any more than variety of food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:3
verses.text: The Lord Himself, therefore, dividing His precepts into what relates to the body, the soul, and thirdly, external things, counsels us to provide external things on account of the body; and manages the body by the soul (ψυκή), and disciplines the soul, saying, "Take no thought for your life (ψυκῆ) what ye shall eat; nor yet for your body, what ye shall put on; for the life is more than meat, and the body more than raiment".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:4
verses.text: And He adds a plain example of instruction: "Consider the ravens: for they neither sow nor reap, which have neither storehouse nor barn; and God feedeth them".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:5
verses.text: "Are ye not better than the fowls?" Thus far as to food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:6
verses.text: Similarly He enjoins with respect to clothing, which belongs to the third division, that of things external, saying, "Consider the lilies, how they spin not, nor weave.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:7
verses.text: But I say unto you, that not even Solomon was arrayed as one of these".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:8
verses.text: " And Solomon the king plumed himself exceedingly on his riches.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:9
verses.text: What, I ask, more graceful, more gay-coloured, than flowers? What, I say, more delightful than lilies or roses? "And if God so clothe the grass, which is to-day in the field, and to-morrow is cast into the oven, how much more will He clothe you, O ye of little faith!" Here the particle what (τί) banishes variety in food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:10
verses.text: For this is shown from the Scripture, "Take no thought what things ye shall eat, or what things ye shall drink".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:11
verses.text: For to take thought of these things argues greed and luxury.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:12
verses.text: Now eating, considered merely by itself, is the sign of necessity; repletion, as we have said, of want.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:13
verses.text: Whatever is beyond that, is the sign of superfluity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:14
verses.text: And what is superfluous, Scripture declares to be of the devil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:15
verses.text: The subjoined expression makes the meaning plain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:16
verses.text: For having said, "Seek not what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink," He added, "Neither be ye of doubtful (or lofty) mind".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:17
verses.text: Now pride and luxury make men waverers (or raise them aloft) from the truth; and the voluptuousness, which indulges in superfluities, leads away from the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:18
verses.text: Wherefore He says very beautifully, "And all these things do the nations of the world seek after".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:19
verses.text: The nations are the dissolute and the foolish.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:20
verses.text: And what are these things which He specifies? Luxury, voluptuousness, rich cooking, dainty feeding, gluttony.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:21
verses.text: These are the "What?" And of bare sustenance, dry and moist, as being necessaries, He says, "Your Father knoweth that ye need these".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:22
verses.text: And if, in a word, we are naturally given to seeking, let us not destroy the faculty of seeking by directing it to luxury, but let us excite it to the discovery of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:23
verses.text: For He says, "Seek ye the kingdom of God, and the materials of sustenance shall be added to you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:24
verses.text: If, then, He takes away anxious care for clothes and food, and superfluities in general, as unnecessary; what are we to imagine ought to be said of love of ornament, and dyeing of wool, and variety of colours, and fastidiousness about gems, and exquisite working of gold, and still more, of artificial hair and wreathed curls; and furthermore, of staining the eyes, and plucking out hairs, and painting with rouge and white lead, and dyeing of the hair, and the wicked arts that are employed in such deceptions? May we not very well suspect, that what was quoted a little above respecting the grass, has been said of those unornamental lovers of ornaments? For the field is the world, and we who are bedewed by the grace of God are the grass; and though cut down, we spring up again, as will be shown at greater length in the book On the Resurrection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:25
verses.text: But hay figuratively designates the vulgar rabble, attached to ephemeral pleasure, flourishing for a little, loving ornament, loving praise, and being everything but truth-loving, good for nothing but to be burned with fire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:26
verses.text: "There was a certain man," said the Lord, narrating, "very rich, who was clothed in purple and scarlet, enjoying himself splendidly every day".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:27
verses.text: This was the hay.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:28
verses.text: "And a certain poor man named Lazarus was laid at the rich man's gate, full of sores, desiring to be filled with the crumbs which fell from the rich man's table".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:29
verses.text: This is the grass.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:30
verses.text: Well, the rich man was punished in Hades, being made partaker of the fire; while the other flourished again in the Father's bosom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:31
verses.text: I admire that ancient city of the Lacedaemonians which permitted harlots alone to wear flowered clothes, and ornaments of gold, interdicting respectable women from love of ornament, and allowing courtesans alone to deck themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:32
verses.text: On the other hand, the archons of the Athenians, who affected a polished mode of life, forgetting their manhood, wore tunics reaching to the feet, and had on the crobulus—a kind of knot of the hair—adorned with a fastening of gold grasshoppers, to show their origin from the soil, forsooth, in the ostentation of licentiousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:33
verses.text: Now rivalry of these archons extended also to the other Ionians, whom Homer, to show their effeminancy, calls "Long-robed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:34
verses.text: Those, therefore, who are devoted to the image of the beautiful, that is, love of finery, not the beautiful itself, and who under a fair name again practice idolatry, are to be banished far from the truth, as those who by opinion, not knowledge, dream of the nature of the beautiful; and so life here is to them only a deep sleep of ignorance; from which it becomes us to rouse ourselves and haste to that which is truly beautiful and comely, and desire to grasp this alone, leaving the ornaments of earth to the world, and bidding them farewell before we fall quite asleep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:35
verses.text: I say, then, that man requires clothes for nothing else than the covering of the body, for defence against excess of cold and intensity of heat, lest the inclemency of the air injure us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:36
verses.text: And if this is the object of clothing, see that one kind be not assigned to men and another to women.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:37
verses.text: For it is common to both to be covered, as it is to eat and drink.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:38
verses.text: The necessity, then, being common, we judge that the provision ought to be similar.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:39
verses.text: For as it is common to both to require things to cover them, so also their coverings ought to be similar; although such a covering ought to be assumed  as is requisite for covering the eyes of women.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:40
verses.text: For if the female sex, on account of their weakness, desire more, we ought to blame the habit of that evil training, by which often men reared up in bad habits become more effeminate than women.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:41
verses.text: But this must not be yielded to.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:42
verses.text: And if some accommodation is to be made, they may be permitted to use softer clothes, provided they put out of the way fabrics foolishly thin, and of curious texture in weaving; bidding farewell to embroidery of gold and Indian silks and elaborate Bombyces (silks), which is at first a worm, then from it is produced a hairy caterpillar; after which the creature suffers a new transformation into a third form which they call larva, from which a long filament is produced, as the spider's thread from the spider.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:43
verses.text: For these superfluous and diaphanous materials are the proof of a weak mind, covering as they do the shame of the body with a slender veil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:44
verses.text: For luxurious clothing, which cannot conceal the shape of the body, is no more a covering.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:45
verses.text: For such clothing, falling close to the body, takes its form more easily, and adhering as it were to the flesh, receives its shape, and marks out the woman's figure, so that the whole make of the body is visible to spectators, though not seeing the body itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:46
verses.text: Dyeing of clothes is also to be rejected.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:47
verses.text: For it is remote both from necessity and truth, in addition to the fact that reproach in manners spring from it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:48
verses.text: For the use of colours is not beneficial, for they are of no service against cold; nor has it anything for covering more than other clothing, except the opprobrium alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:49
verses.text: And the agreeableness of the colour afflicts greedy eyes, inflaming them to senseless blindness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:50
verses.text: But for those who are white and unstained within, it is most suitable to use white and simple garments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:51
verses.text: Clearly and plainly, therefore, Daniel the prophet says, "Thrones were set, and upon them sat one like the Ancient of days, and His vesture was white as snow".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:52
verses.text: The Apocalypse says also that the Lord Himself appeared wearing such a robe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:53
verses.text: It says also, "I saw the souls of those that had witnessed, beneath the altar, and there was given to each a white robe".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:54
verses.text: And if it were necessary to seek for any other colour, the natural colour of truth should suffice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:55
verses.text: But garments which are like flowers are to be abandoned to Bacchic fooleries, and to those of the rites of initiation, along with purple and silver plate, as the comic poet says:—  "Useful for tragedians, not far life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:56
verses.text: And our life ought to be anything rather than a pageant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:57
verses.text: Therefore the dye of Sardis, and another of olive, and another green, a rose-coloured, and scarlet, and ten thousand other dyes, have been invented with much trouble for mischievous voluptuousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:58
verses.text: Such clothing is for looking at, not for covering.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:59
verses.text: Garments, too, variegated with gold, and those that are purple, and that piece of luxury which has its name from beasts (figured on it), and that saffron-coloured ointment-dipped robe, and those costly and many-coloured garments of flaring membranes, we are to bid farewell to, with the art itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:60
verses.text: "For what prudent thing can these women have done," says the comedy, "who sit covered with flowers, wearing a saffron-coloured dress, painted?"  The Instructor expressly admonishes, "Boast not of the clothing of your garment, and be not elated on account of any glory, as it is unlawful".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:61
verses.text: Accordingly, deriding those who are clothed in luxurious garments, He says in the Gospel: "Lo, they who live in gorgeous apparel and luxury are in earthly palaces".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:62
verses.text: He says in perishable palaces, where are love of display, love of popularity, and flattery and deceit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:63
verses.text: But those that wait at the court of heaven around the King of all, are sanctified in the immortal vesture of the Spirit, that is, the flesh, and so put on incorruptibility.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:64
verses.text: As therefore she who is unmarried devotes herself to God alone, and her care is not divided, but the chaste married woman divides her life between God and her husband, while she who is otherwise disposed is devoted entirely to marriage, that is, to passion: in the same way I think the chaste wife, when she devotes herself to her husband, sincerely serves God; but when she becomes fond of finery, she falls away from God and from chaste wedlock, exchanging her husband for the world, after the fashion of that Argive courtesan, I mean Eriphyle,—  "Who received gold prized above her dear husband".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:65
verses.text: Wherefore I admire the Ceian sophist, who delineated like and suitable images of Virtue and Vice, representing the former of these, viz.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:66
verses.text: Virtue, standing simply, white-robed and pure, adorned with modesty alone (for such ought to be the true wife, dowered with modesty).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:67
verses.text: But the other, viz.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:68
verses.text: Vice, on the contrary, he introduces dressed in superfluous attire, brightened up with colour not her own; and her gait and mien are depicted as studiously framed to give pleasure, forming a sketch of wanton women.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:69
verses.text: But he who follows the Word will not addict himself to any base pleasure; wherefore also what is useful in the article of dress is to be preferred.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:70
verses.text: And if the Word, speaking of the Lord by David, sings, "The daughters of kings made Thee glad by honour; the queen stood at Thy right hand, clad in cloth of gold, girt with golden fringes," it is not luxurious raiment that he indicates; but he shows the immortal adornment, woven of faith, of those that have found mercy, that is, the Church; in which the guileless Jesus shines conspicuous as gold, and the elect are the golden tassels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:71
verses.text: And if such must be woven for the women, let us weave apparel pleasant and soft to the touch, not flowered, like pictures, to delight the eye.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:72
verses.text: For the picture fades in course of time, and the washing and steeping in the medicated juices of the dye wear away the wool, and render the fabrics of the garments weak; and this is not favourable to economy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:73
verses.text: It is the height of foolish ostentation to be in a flutter about peploi, and xystides, and ephaptides, and "cloaks," and tunics, and "what covers shame," says Homer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:74
verses.text: For, in truth, I am ashamed when I see so much wealth lavished on the covering of the nakedness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:75
verses.text: For primeval man in Paradise provided a covering for his shame of branches and leaves; and now, since sheep have been created for us, let us not be as silly as sheep, but trained by the Word, let us condemn sumptuousness of clothing, saying, "Ye are sheep's wool".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:76
verses.text: Though Miletus boast, and Italy be praised, and the wool, about which many rave, be protected beneath skins, yet are we not to set our hearts on it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:77
verses.text: The blessed John, despising the locks of sheep as savouring of luxury, chose "camel's hair," and was clad in it, making himself an example of frugality and simplicity of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:78
verses.text: For he also "ate locusts and wild honey," sweet and spiritual fare; preparing, as he was, the lowly and chaste ways of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:79
verses.text: For how possibly could he have worn a purple robe, who turned away from the pomp of cities, and retired to the solitude of the desert, to live in calmness with God, far from all frivolous pursuits—from all false show of good—from all meanness? Elias used a sheepskin mantle, and fastened the sheepskin with a girdle made of hair.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:80
verses.text: And Esaias, another prophet, was naked and barefooted, and often was clad in sackcloth, the garb of humility.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:81
verses.text: And if you call Jeremiah, he had only "a linen girdle".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:82
verses.text: For as well-nurtured bodies, when stripped, show their vigour more manifestly, so also beauty of character shows its magnanimity, when not involved in ostentatious fooleries.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:83
verses.text: But to drag one's clothes, letting them down to the soles of his feet, is a piece of consummate foppery, impeding activity in walking, the garment sweeping the surface dirt of the ground like a broom; since even those emasculated creatures the dancers, who transfer their dumb shameless profligacy to the stage, do not despise the dress which flows away to such indignity; whose curious vestments, and appendages of fringes, and elaborate motions of figures, show the trailing of sordid effeminacy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:84
verses.text: If one should adduce the garment of the Lord reaching down to the foot, that many-flowered coat shows the flowers of wisdom, the varied and unfading Scriptures, the oracles of the Lord, resplendent with the rays of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:85
verses.text: In such another robe the Spirit arrayed the Lord through David, when he sang thus: "Thou wert clothed with confession and comeliness, putting on light as a garment".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:86
verses.text: As, then, in the fashioning of our clothes, we must keep clear of all strangeness, so in the use of them we must beware of extravagance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:87
verses.text: For neither is it seemly for the clothes to be above the knee, as they say was the case with the Lacedaemonian virgins; nor is it becoming for any part of a woman to be exposed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:88
verses.text: Though you may with great propriety use the language addressed to him who said, "Your arm is beautiful; yes, but it is not for the public gaze.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:89
verses.text: Your thighs are beautiful; but, was the reply, for my husband alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:90
verses.text: And your face is comely.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:91
verses.text: Yes; but only for him who has married me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:92
verses.text: But I do not wish chaste women to afford cause for such praises to those who, by praises, hunt after grounds of censure; and not only because it is prohibited to expose the ankle, but because it has also been enjoined that the head should be veiled and the face covered; for it is a wicked thing for beauty to be a snare to men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:93
verses.text: Nor is it seemly for a woman to wish to make herself conspicuous, by using a purple veil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:94
verses.text: Would it were possible to abolish purple in dress, so as not to turn the eyes of spectators on the face of those that wear it! But the women, in the manufacture of all the rest of their dress, have made everything of purple, thus inflaming the lusts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:95
verses.text: And, in truth, those women who are crazy about these stupid and luxurious purples, "purple (dark) death has seized," according to the poetic saying.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:96
verses.text: On account of this purple, then, Tyre and Sidon, and the vicinity of the Lacedaemonian Sea, are very much desired; and their dyers and purple-fishers, and the purple fishes themselves, because their blood produces purple, are held in high esteem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:97
verses.text: But crafty women and effeminate men, who blend these deceptive dyes with dainty fabrics, carry their insane desires beyond all bounds, and export their fine linens no longer from Egypt, but some other kinds from the land of the Hebrews and the Cilicians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:98
verses.text: I say nothing of the linens made of Amorgos and Byssus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:99
verses.text: Luxury has outstripped nomenclature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:100
verses.text: The covering ought, in my judgment, to show that which is covered to be better than itself, as the image is superior to the temple, the soul to the body, and the body to the clothes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:101
verses.text: But now, quite the contrary, the body of these ladies, if sold, would never fetch a thousand Attic drachms.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:102
verses.text: Buying, as they do, a single dress at the price of ten thousand talents, they prove themselves to be of less use and less value than cloth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 12:103
verses.text: Why in the world do you seek after what is rare and costly, in preference to what is at hand and cheap? It is because you know not what is really beautiful, what is really good, and seek with eagerness shows instead of realities from fools who, like people out of their wits, imagine black to be white.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:1
verses.text: Chapter - 12—On Shoes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:2
verses.text: Women fond of display act in the same manner with regard to shoes, showing also in this matter great luxuriousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:3
verses.text: Base, in truth, are those sandals on which golden ornaments are fastened; but they are thought worth having nails driven into the soles in winding rows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:4
verses.text: Many, too, carve on them amorous embraces, as if they would by their walk communicate to the earth harmonious movement, and impress on it the wantonness of their spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:5
verses.text: Farewell, therefore, must be bidden to gold-plated and jewelled mischievous devices of sandals, and Attic and Sicyonian half-boots, and Persian and Tyrrhenian buskins; and setting before us the right aim, as is the habit with our truth, we are bound to select what is in accordance with nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:6
verses.text: For the use of shoes is partly for covering, partly for defence in case of stumbling against objects, and for saving the sole of the foot from the roughness of hilly paths.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:7
verses.text: Women are to be allowed a white shoe, except when on a journey, and then a greased shoe must be used.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:8
verses.text: When on a journey, they require nailed shoes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:9
verses.text: Further, they ought for the most part to wear shoes; for it is not suitable for the foot to be shown naked: besides, woman is a tender thing, easily hurt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:10
verses.text: But for a man bare feet are quite in keeping, except when he is on military service.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:11
verses.text: "For being shod is near neighbour to being bound".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:12
verses.text: To go with bare feet is most suitable for exercise, and best adapted for health and ease, unless where necessity prevents.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:13
verses.text: But if we are not on a journey, and cannot endure bare feet, we may use slippers or white shoes; dusty-foots the Attics called them, on account of their bringing the feet near the dust, as I think.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:14
verses.text: As a witness for simplicity in shoes let John suffice, who avowed that "he was not worthy to unloose the latchet of the Lord's shoes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:15
verses.text: For he who exhibited to the Hebrews the type of the true philosophy wore no elaborate shoes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 13:16
verses.text: What else this may imply, will be shown elsewhere.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII—Against Excessive Fondness for Jewels and Gold Ornaments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:2
verses.text: It is childish to admire excessively dark or green stones, and things cast out by the sea on foreign shores, particles of the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:3
verses.text: For to rush after stones that are pellucid and of peculiar colours, and stained glass, is only characteristic of silly people, who are attracted by things that have a striking show.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:4
verses.text: Thus children, on seeing the fire, rush to it, attracted by its brightness; not understanding through senselessness the danger of touching it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:5
verses.text: Such is the case with the stones which silly women wear fastened to chains and set in necklaces, amethysts, ceraunites, jaspers, topaz, and the Milesian  "Emerald, most precious ware".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:6
verses.text: And the highly prized pearl has invaded the woman's apartments to an extravagant extent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:7
verses.text: This is produced in a kind of oyster like mussels, and is about the bigness of a fish's eye of large size.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:8
verses.text: And the wretched creatures are not ashamed at having bestowed the greatest pains about this little oyster, when they might adorn themselves with the sacred jewel, the Word of God, whom the Scripture has somewhere called a pearl, the pure and pellucid Jesus, the eye that watches in the flesh,—the transparent Word, by whom the flesh, regenerated by water, becomes precious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:9
verses.text: For that oyster that is in the water covers the flesh all round, and out of it is produced the pearl.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:10
verses.text: We have heard, too, that the Jerusalem above is walled with sacred stones; and we allow that the twelve gates of the celestial city, by being made like precious stones, indicate the transcendent grace of the apostolic voice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:11
verses.text: For the colours are laid on in precious stones, and these colours are precious; while the other parts remain of earthy material.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:12
verses.text: With these symbolically, as is meet, the city of the saints, which is spiritually built, is walled.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:13
verses.text: By that brilliancy of stones, therefore, is meant the inimitable brilliancy of the spirit, the immortality and sanctity of being.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:14
verses.text: But these women, who comprehend not the symbolism of Scripture, gape all they can for jewels, adducing the astounding apology, "Why may I not use what God hath exhibited?" and, "I have it by me, why may I not enjoy it?" and, "For whom were these things made, then, if not for us?" Such are the utterances of those who are totally ignorant of the will of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:15
verses.text: For first necessaries, such as water and air, He supplies free to all; and what is not necessary He has hid in the earth and water.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:16
verses.text: Wherefore ants dig, and griffins guard gold, and the sea hides the pearl-stone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:17
verses.text: But ye busy yourselves about what you need not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:18
verses.text: Behold, the whole heaven is lighted up, and ye seek not God; but gold which is hidden, and jewels, are dug up by those among us who are condemned to death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:19
verses.text: But you also oppose Scripture, seeing it expressly cries "Seek first the kingdom of heaven, and all these things shall be added unto you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:20
verses.text: But if all things have been conferred on you, and all things allowed you, and "if all things are lawful, yet all things are not expedient," says the apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:21
verses.text: God brought our race into communion by first imparting what was His own, when He gave His own Word, common to all, and made all things for all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:22
verses.text: All things therefore are common, and not for the rich to appropriate an undue share.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:23
verses.text: That expression, therefore, "I possess, and possess in abundance: why then should I not enjoy?" is suitable neither to the man, nor to society.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:24
verses.text: But more worthy of love is that: "I have: why should I not give to those who need?" For such an one—one who fulfils the command, "Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself"—is perfect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:25
verses.text: For this is the true luxury—the treasured wealth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:26
verses.text: But that which is squandered on foolish lusts is to be reckoned waste, not expenditure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:27
verses.text: For God has given to us, I know well, the liberty of use, but only so far as necessary; and He has determined that the use should be common.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:28
verses.text: And it is monstrous for one to live in luxury, while many are in want.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:29
verses.text: How much more glorious is it to do good to many, than to live sumptuously! How much wiser to spend money on human being, than on jewels and gold! How much more useful to acquire decorous friends, than lifeless ornaments! Whom have lands ever benefited so much as conferring favours has? It remains for us, therefore, to do away with this allegation: Who, then, will have the more sumptuous things, if all select the simpler? Men, I would say, if they make use of them impartially and indifferently.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:30
verses.text: But if it be impossible for all to exercise self-restraint, yet, with a view to the use of what is necessary, we must seek after what can be most readily procured, bidding a long farewell to these superfluities.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:31
verses.text: In fine, they must accordingly utterly cast off ornaments as girls' gewgaws, rejecting adornment itself entirely.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:32
verses.text: For they ought to be adorned within, and show the inner woman beautiful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:33
verses.text: For in the soul alone are beauty and deformity shown.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:34
verses.text: Wherefore also only the virtuous man is really beautiful and good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:35
verses.text: And it is laid down as a dogma, that only the beautiful is good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:36
verses.text: And excellence alone appears through the beautiful body, and blossoms out in the flesh, exhibiting the amiable comeliness of self-control, whenever the character like a beam of light gleams in the form.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:37
verses.text: For the beauty of each plant and animal consists in its individual excellence.
