verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:38
verses.text: And the excellence of man is righteousness, and temperance, and manliness, and godliness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:39
verses.text: The beautiful man is, then, he who is just, temperate, and in a word, good, not he who is rich.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:40
verses.text: But now even the soldiers wish to be decked with gold, not having read that poetical saying:—  "With childish folly to the war he came, Laden with store of gold".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:41
verses.text: But the love of ornament, which is far from caring for virtue, but claims the body for itself, when the love of the beautiful has changed to empty show, is to be utterly expelled.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:42
verses.text: For applying things unsuitable to the body, as if they were suitable, begets a practice of lying and a habit of falsehood; and shows not what is decorous, simple, and truly childlike, but what is pompous, luxurious, and effeminate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:43
verses.text: But these women obscure true beauty, shading it with gold.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:44
verses.text: And they know not how great is their transgression, in fastening around themselves ten thousand rich chains; as they say that among the barbarians malefactors are bound with gold.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:45
verses.text: The women seem to me to emulate these rich prisoners.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:46
verses.text: For is not the golden necklace a collar, and do not the necklets which they call catheters occupy the place of chains? and indeed  among the Attics they are called by this very name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:47
verses.text: The ungraceful things round the feet of women, Philemon in the Synephebus called ankle-fetters:—  "Conspicuous garments, and a kind of a golden fetter".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:48
verses.text: What else, then, is this coveted adorning of yourselves, O ladies, but the exhibiting of yourselves fettered? For if the material does away with the reproach, the endurance of your fetters is a thing indifferent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:49
verses.text: To me, then, those who voluntarily put themselves into bonds seem to glory in rich calamities.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:50
verses.text: Perchance also it is such chains that the poetic fable says were thrown around Aphrodite when committing adultery, referring to ornaments as nothing but the badge of adultery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:51
verses.text: For Homer called those, too, golden chains.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:52
verses.text: But new women are not ashamed to wear the most manifest badges of the evil one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:53
verses.text: For as the serpent deceived Eve, so also has ornament of gold maddened other women to vicious practices, using as a bait the form of the serpent, and by fashioning lampreys and serpents for decoration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:54
verses.text: Accordingly the comic poet Nicostratus says, "Chains, collars, rings, bracelets, serpents, anklets, earrings".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:55
verses.text: In terms of strongest censure, therefore, Aristophanes in the Thesmophoriazousae exhibits the whole array of female ornament in a catalogue:—  "Snoods, fillets, natron, and steel; Pumice-stone, band, back-band, Back-veil, paint, necklaces, Paints for the eyes, soft garment, hair-net, Girdle, shawl, fine purple border, Long robe, tunic, Barathrum, round tunic".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:56
verses.text: But I have not yet mentioned the principal of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:57
verses.text: Then what?  "Ear-pendants, jewelry, ear-rings; Mallow-coloured cluster-shaped anklets; Buckles, clasps, necklets, Fetters, seals, chains, rings, powders, Bosses, bands, olisbi, Sardian stones, Fans, helicters".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:58
verses.text: I am weary and vexed at enumerating the multitude of ornaments; and I am compelled to wonder how those who bear such a burden are not worried to death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:59
verses.text: O foolish trouble! O silly craze for display! They squander meretriciously wealth on what is disgraceful; and in their love for ostentation disfigure God's gifts, emulating the art of the evil one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:60
verses.text: The rich man hoarding up in his barns, and saying to himself, "Thou hast much goods laid up for many years; eat, drink, be merry," the Lord in the Gospel plainly called "fool".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:61
verses.text: "For this night they shall take of thee thy soul; whose then shall those things which thou hast prepared be?"  Apelles, the painter, seeing one of his pupils painting a figure loaded with gold colour to represent Helen, said to him, "Boy, being incapable of painting her beautiful, you have made her rich".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:62
verses.text: Such Helens are the ladies of the present day, not truly beautiful, but richly got up.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:63
verses.text: To these the Spirit prophesies by Zephaniah: "And their silver and their gold shall not be able to deliver them in the day of the Lord's anger".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:64
verses.text: But for those women who have been trained under Christ, it is suitable to adorn themselves not with gold, but with the Word, through whom alone the gold comes to light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:65
verses.text: Happy, then, would have been the ancient Hebrews, had they cast away their women's ornaments, or only melted them; but having cast their gold into the form of an ox, and paid it idolatrous worship, they consequently reap no advantage either from their art or their attempt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:66
verses.text: But they taught our women most expressively to keep clear of ornaments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:67
verses.text: The lust which commits fornication with gold becomes an idol, and is tested by fire; for which alone luxury is reserved, as being an idol, not a reality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:68
verses.text: Hence the Word, upbraiding the Hebrews by the prophet, says, "They made to Baal things of silver and gold," that is, ornaments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:69
verses.text: And most distinctly threatening, He says, "I will punish her for the days of Baalim, in which they offered sacrifice for her, and she put on her earrings and her necklaces".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:70
verses.text: And He subjoined the cause of the adornment, when He said, "And she went after her lovers, but forgot Me, saith the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:71
verses.text: Resigning, therefore, these baubles to the wicked master of cunning himself, let us not take part in this meretricious adornment, nor commit idolatry through a specious pretext.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:72
verses.text: Most admirably, therefore, the blessed Peter says, "In like manner also, that women adorn themselves not with braids, or gold, or costly array, but (which becometh women professing godliness) with good works".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:73
verses.text: For it is with reason that he bids decking of themselves to be kept far from them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:74
verses.text: For, granting that they are beautiful, nature suffices.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:75
verses.text: Let not art contend against nature; that is, let not falsehood strive with truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:76
verses.text: And if they are by nature ugly, they are convicted, by the things they apply to themselves, of what they do not possess i-e:, of the want of beauty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:77
verses.text: It is suitable, therefore, for women who serve Christ to adopt simplicity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:78
verses.text: For in reality simplicity provides for sanctity, by reducing redundancies to equality, and by furnishing from whatever is at hand the enjoyment sought from superfluities.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:79
verses.text: For simplicity, as the name shows, is not conspicuous, is not inflated or puffed up in aught, but is altogether even, and gentle, and equal, and free of excess, and so is sufficient.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:80
verses.text: And sufficiency is a condition which reaches its proper end without excess or defect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:81
verses.text: The mother of these is Justice, and their nurse "Independence;" and this is a condition which is satisfied with what is necessary, and by itself furnishes what contributes to the blessed life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:82
verses.text: Let there, then, be in the fruits of thy hands, sacred order, liberal communication, and acts of economy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:83
verses.text: "For he that giveth to the poor, lendeth to God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:84
verses.text: "And the hands of the manly shall be enriched".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:85
verses.text: Manly He calls those who despise wealth, and are free in bestowing it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:86
verses.text: And on your feet let active readiness to well-doing appear, and a journeying to righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:87
verses.text: Modesty and chastity are collars and necklaces; such are the chains which God forges.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:88
verses.text: "Happy is the man who hath found wisdom, and the mortal who knows understanding," says the Spirit by Solomon: "for it is better to buy her than treasures of gold and silver; and she is more valuable than precious stones".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:89
verses.text: For she is the true decoration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:90
verses.text: And let not their ears be pierced, contrary to nature, in order to attach to them ear-rings and ear-drops.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:91
verses.text: For it is not right to force nature against her wishes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:92
verses.text: Nor could there be any better ornament for the ears than true instruction, which finds its way naturally into the passages of hearing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book II 14:93
verses.text: And eyes anointed by the Word, and ears pierced for perception, make a man a hearer and contemplator of divine and sacred things, the Word truly exhibiting the true beauty "which eye hath not seen nor ear heard before".
